It&#39;s how reading on the mobile web should be—fast, responsive and fun.  &lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-v4HwU0Bb2H4/Vs0mLBtKsqI/AAAAAAAAR3c/JfjaZcVl3hc/s1600/AMP_v6_phone_cropped.mov.gif&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;640&quot; src=&quot;https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-v4HwU0Bb2H4/Vs0mLBtKsqI/AAAAAAAAR3c/JfjaZcVl3hc/s640/AMP_v6_phone_cropped.mov.gif&quot; width=&quot;384&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;While helping people find fast AMP content through Google Search is a significant step, there’s still a lot of work ahead for the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ampproject.org/&quot;&gt;open source AMP Project&lt;/a&gt;. Still, it’s been thrilling to see how the industry has come together to work on this common goal of making the mobile web great for everyone. And given the potential AMP holds for other types of content, we’re excited about what the future holds.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;byline-author&quot;&gt;Posted by David Besbris, VP Engineering, Search&lt;/span&gt;  &lt;span data-about-syndication=&quot;&quot; style=&quot;display: none; font-size: 0; line-height: 0; max-height: 0; overflow: hidden;&quot;&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-image&quot;&gt;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-AstzXdmDwhg/Vs5OXT22dWI/AAAAAAAAR4Q/bQLXTpG9MZg/s1600/AMP%2Bhero.jpg&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-name&quot;&gt;David Besbris&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-title&quot;&gt;VP Engineering&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-team&quot;&gt;Search&lt;/span&gt; &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;</content><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/8969855062473424319'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/8969855062473424319'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2016/02/amping-up-in-mobile-search.html' title='AMPing up in mobile Search '/><author><name>Google Blogs</name><uri>https://plus.google.com/112374322230920073195</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//lh3.googleusercontent.com/-SMZmHeOVbFs/AAAAAAAAAAI/AAAAAAAAR7c/esUAZEvmr9M/s512-c/photo.jpg'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-v4HwU0Bb2H4/Vs0mLBtKsqI/AAAAAAAAR3c/JfjaZcVl3hc/s72-c/AMP_v6_phone_cropped.mov.gif" height="72" width="72"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentSource" value="1"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentModerationMode" value="FILTERED_POSTMOD"/></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-10861780.post-3279196200662078043</id><published>2016-02-23T00:01:00.000-08:00</published><updated>2016-02-24T16:47:14.144-08:00</updated><title type='text'>Google Science Fair 2016: #howcanwe make things better with science?</title><content type='html'>&lt;i&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://googlesciencefair.com/?utm_source=google%20brand%20blogpost&amp;amp;utm_medium=google%20brand%20blogpost&amp;amp;utm_campaign=GSF2016launch&quot;&gt;2016 Google Science Fair&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;opens for submissions today. Together with LEGO Education, National Geographic, Scientific American and Virgin Galactic, we’re inviting all young explorers and innovators to make something better through science and engineering. To learn more about the competition, how to enter, prize details and more, visit the &lt;a href=&quot;http://googlesciencefair.com/?utm_source=google%20brand%20blogpost&amp;amp;utm_medium=google%20brand%20blogpost&amp;amp;utm_campaign=GSF2016launch&quot;&gt;site&lt;/a&gt;, and &lt;a href=&quot;https://plus.google.com/+GoogleScienceFair/posts&quot;&gt;follow along on Google+&lt;/a&gt;  and &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/googlescifair&quot;&gt;Twitter&lt;/a&gt;.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;In this post,&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m7f3SxVvlPY&quot;&gt;2015 Grand Prize winner, Olivia Hallisey,&lt;/a&gt; joins us to reflect back on her own experience with Google Science Fair. &lt;/i&gt;-Ed.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-eFfjPTcYOxY/VsvSjzcFe7I/AAAAAAAAR3E/olDJGnK9srs/s1600/OLIVIA_GSF_1.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;360&quot; src=&quot;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-eFfjPTcYOxY/VsvSjzcFe7I/AAAAAAAAR3E/olDJGnK9srs/s640/OLIVIA_GSF_1.jpg&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;I remember the day I first heard about the Google Science Fair last year. I was sitting in my 10th grade science class when my teacher asked us: “What will you try?” I loved the invitation—and the challenge—that the Google Science Fair offered. It was a chance to use science to do something that could really make a difference in the world.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;I had always been curious and interested in science, and knew I wanted to submit a project, but didn’t really know exactly where to begin. I asked my teacher for his advice on selecting a research topic. He encouraged me to choose something that I felt passionate about, or something that outraged me, and told me to look at the world around me for inspiration. So I did. At that time, the Ebola crisis was all over the news. It was a devastating situation and I wanted to help be a part of the solution. I had found my project. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;With the outbreak spreading so quickly, I decided that I wanted to find a way to diagnose the virus earlier so that treatment could be delivered as quickly as possible to those who were affected. I read online about silk’s amazing storage and stabilizing properties, and wondered if I could use silk to transport antibodies that could test for the virus. After many failed attempts (and cutting up lots of cocoons) I finally succeeded in creating a temperature-independent, portable, and inexpensive diagnostic test that could detect the Ebola virus in under 30 minutes. I was really excited that my research could help contribute to saving lives, and I was proud to be selected as the Grand Prize winner a few months later.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;As the 2016 Google Science Fair launches today, I wanted to share a few tips from my own experience: First, as my teacher once guided me to do, look at the world around you for ideas. If you’re stuck, try the &lt;a href=&quot;http://googlesciencefair.com/make-better-generator/en/&quot;&gt;Make Better Generator&lt;/a&gt; to find something that excites or inspires you. Second, find a mentor who’s interested in the same things as you. There are a lot of &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.googlesciencefair.com/en/participants&quot;&gt;helpful ideas&lt;/a&gt; on the GSF site to get you started. And finally, don’t get discouraged—often what first appears like failure can teach you so much more. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;I urge other teenagers like me to take this opportunity to find a way to make the world around them better. Every one of us, no matter our age or background, can make a difference—and as young people, we’re not always so afraid to try things that adults think will fail. But change doesn’t happen overnight, and it often starts with a question. So look at the world around you and challenge yourself to make something better.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;iframe allowfullscreen=&quot;&quot; frameborder=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;360&quot; src=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/embed/jYAAOdJcqTQ&quot; width=&quot;640&quot;&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Science isn’t just a subject—it’s a way to make things better. So I hope you’ll join the &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/googlescifair&quot;&gt;conversation&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;http://googlesciencefair.com/?utm_source=officialgoogleblog&amp;amp;utm_medium=officialgoogleblog&amp;amp;utm_campaign=gsf2016&quot;&gt;enter the Google Science Fair this year&lt;/a&gt;. Our world is waiting to see what you come up with!&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-t6-QTZDTaNM/VsvSjzIalrI/AAAAAAAAR3I/5Vj_WlkqD2k/s1600/Screen%2BShot%2B2016-02-20%2Bat%2B7.24.28%2BAM.png&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;355&quot; src=&quot;https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-t6-QTZDTaNM/VsvSjzIalrI/AAAAAAAAR3I/5Vj_WlkqD2k/s640/Screen%2BShot%2B2016-02-20%2Bat%2B7.24.28%2BAM.png&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;byline-author&quot;&gt;Posted by Olivia Hallisey, 2015 Grand Prize winner, Google Science Fair&lt;/span&gt;  &lt;span data-about-syndication=&quot;&quot; style=&quot;display: none; font-size: 0; line-height: 0; max-height: 0; overflow: hidden;&quot;&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-image&quot;&gt;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-AdD3J4PHv_A/Vs5OXbEltKI/AAAAAAAAR4M/IMUAo3p9JXU/s1600/Science%2BFair.jpg&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-name&quot;&gt;Olivia Hallisey&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-title&quot;&gt;2015 Grand Prize winner&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-team&quot;&gt;Google Science Fair&lt;/span&gt; &lt;/span&gt;</content><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/3279196200662078043'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/3279196200662078043'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2016/02/google-science-fair-2016-howcanwe-make.html' title='Google Science Fair 2016: #howcanwe make things better with science?'/><author><name>Google Blogs</name><uri>https://plus.google.com/112374322230920073195</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//lh3.googleusercontent.com/-SMZmHeOVbFs/AAAAAAAAAAI/AAAAAAAAR7c/esUAZEvmr9M/s512-c/photo.jpg'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-eFfjPTcYOxY/VsvSjzcFe7I/AAAAAAAAR3E/olDJGnK9srs/s72-c/OLIVIA_GSF_1.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentSource" value="1"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentModerationMode" value="FILTERED_POSTMOD"/></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-10861780.post-189606000734960069</id><published>2016-02-09T09:03:00.001-08:00</published><updated>2016-02-11T14:40:29.767-08:00</updated><title type='text'>Building a safer web, for everyone </title><content type='html'>Today is &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.saferinternetday.org/web/usa/sid&quot;&gt;Safer Internet Day&lt;/a&gt;, a moment for technology companies, nonprofit organizations, security firms, and people around the world to focus on online safety, together. To mark the occasion, we’re rolling out new tools, and some useful reminders, to help protect you from online dangers of all stripes—phishing, malware, and other threats to your personal information.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;1. Keeping security settings simple&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;https://security.google.com/settings/security/secureaccount?utm_source=ogb-blog&amp;amp;utm_medium=blog-pr&amp;amp;utm_campaign=safer-internet-day&quot;&gt;Security Checkup&lt;/a&gt; is a quick way to control the security settings for your Google Account. You can add a recovery phone number so we can help if you’re ever locked out of your account, strengthen your password settings, see which devices are connected to your account, and more. If you complete the Security Checkup by February 11, you’ll also get &lt;a href=&quot;http://googledrive.blogspot.com/2016/02/safer-internet-day-2016.html&quot;&gt;2GB of extra Google Drive storage&lt;/a&gt;, which can be used across Google Drive, Gmail, and Photos.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Safer Internet Day is a great time to do it, but you can—and should!—take a Security Checkup on a regular basis. Start your Security Checkup by visiting &lt;a href=&quot;https://myaccount.google.com/&quot;&gt;My Account&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-WdNReAvdDFM/VrocQdIoHbI/AAAAAAAAR1M/SEBM2vUBMog/s1600/SID_FB_001.gif&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;480&quot; src=&quot;https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-WdNReAvdDFM/VrocQdIoHbI/AAAAAAAAR1M/SEBM2vUBMog/s640/SID_FB_001.gif&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;b&gt;2. Informing Gmail users about potentially unsafe messages&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;If you and your Grandpa both use Gmail to exchange messages, your connections are &lt;a href=&quot;http://gmailblog.blogspot.com/2014/03/staying-at-forefront-of-email-security.html&quot;&gt;encrypted&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://googleonlinesecurity.blogspot.com/2013/12/internet-wide-efforts-to-fight-email.html&quot;&gt;authenticated&lt;/a&gt;. That means no peering eyes can read those emails as they zoom across the web, and you can be confident that the message from your Grandpa in size 48 font (with no punctuation and a few misspellings) is really from him!&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;However, as our &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/transparencyreport/saferemail/&quot;&gt;Safer Email Transparency Report&lt;/a&gt; explains, these things are not always true when Gmail interacts with other mail services. Today, we’re introducing changes in Gmail on the web to let people know when a received message was not encrypted, if you’re composing a message to a recipient whose email service doesn’t support TLS encryption, or when the sender’s domain couldn’t be authenticated.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Here’s the notice you’ll see in Gmail before you send a message to a service that doesn’t support &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.google.com/transparencyreport/saferemail/tls/?hl=en&quot;&gt;TLS encryption&lt;/a&gt;. You’ll also see the broken lock icon if you receive a message that was sent without TLS&amp;nbsp;encryption.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-2H0Pf1jkirM/VrobB3zsSlI/AAAAAAAAR08/nOOdmWNsfRw/s1600/notice%2Bone.gif&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;580&quot; src=&quot;https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-2H0Pf1jkirM/VrobB3zsSlI/AAAAAAAAR08/nOOdmWNsfRw/s640/notice%2Bone.gif&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;If you receive a message that can’t be authenticated, you’ll see a question mark where you might otherwise see a profile photo or logo:&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-L1oJKr37ukw/VrobVIVMh3I/AAAAAAAAR1E/PywRm61EP9A/s1600/notice%2B2.png&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;320&quot; src=&quot;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-L1oJKr37ukw/VrobVIVMh3I/AAAAAAAAR1E/PywRm61EP9A/s640/notice%2B2.png&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;b&gt;3. Protecting you from bad apps&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Dangerous apps that phish and steal your personal information, or hold your phone hostage and make you pay to unlock it, have no place on your smartphone—or any device, for that matter.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Google Play helps protect your Android device by rejecting bad apps that don’t comply with our &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.android.com/us/developer-content-policy.html#showlanguages&quot;&gt;Play policies&lt;/a&gt;. It also conducts more than 200 million daily security scans of devices, in tandem with our &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/transparencyreport/safebrowsing/&quot;&gt;Safe Browsing&lt;/a&gt; system, for any signs of trouble. Last year, bad apps were installed on fewer than 0.13% of Android devices that install apps only from Google Play.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Learn more about these, and other Android security features — like app sandboxing, &lt;a href=&quot;http://officialandroid.blogspot.com/2015/08/an-update-to-nexus-devices.html&quot;&gt;monthly security updates&lt;/a&gt; for Nexus and other devices, and our &lt;a href=&quot;https://googleonlinesecurity.blogspot.com/2015/06/announcing-security-rewards-for-android.html&quot;&gt;Security Rewards Program&lt;/a&gt;—in new research we’ve made public on our &lt;a href=&quot;http://officialandroid.blogspot.com/2016/02/safety-first-four-easy-android-security.html&quot;&gt;Android blog&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;4. Busting bad advertising practices &lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Malicious advertising “botnets” try to send phony visitors to websites to make money from online ads. Botnets threaten the businesses of honest advertisers and publishers, and because they’re often made up of devices infected with malware, they put users in harm’s way too. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;We&#39;ve worked to keep botnets out of our ads systems, cutting them out of advertising revenue, and making it harder to make money from distributing malware and &lt;a href=&quot;https://googleonlinesecurity.blogspot.com/2015/12/year-one-progress-in-fight-against.html&quot;&gt;Unwanted Software&lt;/a&gt;. Now, as part of our effort to &lt;a href=&quot;https://googleblog.blogspot.com/2016/01/better-ads-report.html&quot;&gt;fight bad ads online&lt;/a&gt;, we’re reinforcing our existing botnet defenses by automatically filtering traffic from three of the top ad fraud botnets, comprising more than 500,000 infected user machines. Learn more about this update on the &lt;a href=&quot;http://doubleclickadvertisers.blogspot.com/2016/02/booting-bots-new-botnet-protections.html&quot;&gt;Doubleclick blog&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;5. Moving the security conversation forward &lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Recent events—&lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Snowden#Global_surveillance_disclosures&quot;&gt;Edward Snowden’s disclosures&lt;/a&gt;, the &lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sony_Pictures_Entertainment_hack&quot;&gt;Sony Hack&lt;/a&gt;, the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2015/12/08/you-already-use-encryption-heres-what-you-need-to-know-about-it/&quot;&gt;current conversation around encryption&lt;/a&gt;, and more—have made online safety a truly mainstream issue. This is reflected both in news headlines, and popular culture: “&lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mr._Robot_(TV_series)&quot;&gt;Mr. Robot&lt;/a&gt;,” a TV series about hacking and cybersecurity, just won a Golden Globe for Best Drama, and &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/SwiftOnSecurity&quot;&gt;@SwiftOnSecurity&lt;/a&gt;, a popular security commentator, is named after Taylor Swift. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;But despite this shift, security remains a complex topic that lends itself to lively debates between experts...that are often unintelligible to just about everyone else. We need to simplify the way we talk about online security to enable everyone to understand its importance and participate in this conversation.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;To that end, we’re teaming up with &lt;a href=&quot;https://medium.com/&quot;&gt;Medium&lt;/a&gt; to host a virtual roundtable about online security, present and future. Moderated by journalist and security researcher &lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevin_Poulsen&quot;&gt;Kevin Poulsen&lt;/a&gt;, this project aims to present fresh perspectives about online security in a time when our attention is increasingly ruled by the devices we carry with us constantly. We hope you’ll &lt;a href=&quot;http://me.dm/roundtable&quot;&gt;tune in&lt;/a&gt; and check it out.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Online security and safety are being discussed more often, and with more urgency, than ever before. We hope you’ll take a few minutes today to learn how Google protects your data and how we can work toward a safer web, for everyone.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;byline-author&quot;&gt;Posted by Gerhard Eschelbeck, VP, Security and Privacy&lt;/span&gt;  &lt;span data-about-syndication=&quot;&quot; style=&quot;display: none; font-size: 0; line-height: 0; max-height: 0; overflow: hidden;&quot;&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-image&quot;&gt;https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-ULzOadjY19s/Vr0Nptiu2II/AAAAAAAAR1s/1CC_5AacxzU/s1600/GOP-security_hero_1.jpg&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-name&quot;&gt; Gerhard Eschelbeck&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-title&quot;&gt;VP&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-team&quot;&gt;Security and Privacy&lt;/span&gt; &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/189606000734960069'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/189606000734960069'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2016/02/building-safer-web-for-everyone.html' title='Building a safer web, for everyone '/><author><name>Google Blogs</name><uri>https://plus.google.com/112374322230920073195</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//lh3.googleusercontent.com/-SMZmHeOVbFs/AAAAAAAAAAI/AAAAAAAAR7c/esUAZEvmr9M/s512-c/photo.jpg'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-WdNReAvdDFM/VrocQdIoHbI/AAAAAAAAR1M/SEBM2vUBMog/s72-c/SID_FB_001.gif" height="72" width="72"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentSource" value="1"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentModerationMode" value="FILTERED_POSTMOD"/></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-10861780.post-620319181575642742</id><published>2016-02-05T06:00:00.000-08:00</published><updated>2016-02-11T14:43:19.879-08:00</updated><category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="doodles"/><category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="education"/><title type='text'>From antiques to pizza, see what went into making this year’s masterpieces for Doodle 4 Google</title><content type='html'>Last October, we kicked off our annual &lt;a href=&quot;http://google.com/doodle4google/?utm_source=ogb2&amp;amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;amp;utm_campaign=d4g15&quot;&gt;Doodle 4 Google&lt;/a&gt; art competition, asking students to create a doodle to tell the world “What makes me…me.” This time around, we added a little twist: for the first time in eight years of Doodle 4 Google, there were no restrictions on the medium or materials kids could use to create a doodle. Kids took us up on the challenge. A quarter of all finalists used some non-traditional media—from clay and wood to origami, photographs and sheets of music—in their submission. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Today, Googlers are hosting surprise assemblies at schools from Waterville, Maine to Waipahu, Hawaii to celebrate the winners of each state and thank the teachers and parents who have encouraged them along the way. And for the first time ever, we’re announcing winners for Washington, D.C., Guam and Puerto Rico. See all &lt;a href=&quot;http://google.com/doodle4google/vote.html?utm_source=ogb2&amp;amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;amp;utm_campaign=d4g15&quot;&gt;53 State and Territory Winner&lt;/a&gt;s on our website.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-n1T7wJ8BU3s/VrQuNJBNVeI/AAAAAAAAR0k/uecYY5zg3LQ/s1600/D4G.gif&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;315&quot; src=&quot;https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-n1T7wJ8BU3s/VrQuNJBNVeI/AAAAAAAAR0k/uecYY5zg3LQ/s640/D4G.gif&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Now, our finalists need your votes for a shot at having their doodle make it onto the Google homepage. Starting today through Feb 22, head to the &lt;a href=&quot;http://google.com/doodle4google/?utm_source=ogb2&amp;amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;amp;utm_campaign=d4g15&quot;&gt;Doodle 4 Google site&lt;/a&gt; to vote for your favorite artwork for each grade group. On March 21, we’ll announce the winner and four runners-up—and you’ll see the winning doodle on google.com.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Check out this year’s talented set of finalists and &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.google.com/doodle4google/vote.html?utm_source=ogb2&amp;amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;amp;utm_campaign=d4g15&quot;&gt;vote&lt;/a&gt; for your favorite!&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: &amp;quot;arial&amp;quot;; font-size: 13.3333px; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;byline-author&quot;&gt;Posted by Ryan Germick, Doodler and non-traditional media enthusiast&lt;/span&gt;  &lt;span data-about-syndication=&quot;&quot; style=&quot;display: none; font-size: 0; line-height: 0; max-height: 0; overflow: hidden;&quot;&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-image&quot;&gt;https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-GUyXFVIM5v0/Vr0NpnRF_oI/AAAAAAAAR1w/-TqIUz7WaH8/s1600/GOP-d4g_hero_1.jpg&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-name&quot;&gt;Ryan Germick&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-title&quot;&gt;Doodler&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/620319181575642742'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/620319181575642742'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2016/02/from-antiques-to-pizza-see-what-went.html' title='From antiques to pizza, see what went into making this year’s masterpieces for Doodle 4 Google'/><author><name>Google Blogs</name><uri>https://plus.google.com/112374322230920073195</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//lh3.googleusercontent.com/-SMZmHeOVbFs/AAAAAAAAAAI/AAAAAAAAR7c/esUAZEvmr9M/s512-c/photo.jpg'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-n1T7wJ8BU3s/VrQuNJBNVeI/AAAAAAAAR0k/uecYY5zg3LQ/s72-c/D4G.gif" height="72" width="72"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentSource" value="1"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentModerationMode" value="FILTERED_POSTMOD"/></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-10861780.post-5996013638035979764</id><published>2016-02-01T03:00:00.000-08:00</published><updated>2016-02-01T08:24:38.468-08:00</updated><title type='text'>Preserving and celebrating Black history, arts and culture</title><content type='html'>Growing up, my parents were daily reminders of the sacrifices made by earlier generations of Black Americans to give people like me the opportunities they were denied. To this day, their stories propel me to continue the fight for justice. I am far from alone—reflecting on a shared history inspires millions around the world to work toward equality. But without some record, those stories and the passion they ignite could get lost.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Artworks, artifacts and archives have the power not only to give a story life, but to encourage action and incite change. That’s why the Google Cultural Institute is excited to add records from institutions like the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture, the Studio Museum and Amistad Research Center and many more—bringing together &lt;a href=&quot;http://g.co/blackhistory&quot;&gt;important archives from Black history&lt;/a&gt; for anyone to access not only during Black History Month, but throughout the year. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;From the New Orleans Jazz Orchestra to the historical records of Frederick Douglass and Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., this collection includes 26 new institutions (50 overall) contributing &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/browse/?q.openId=8129907598665562501&amp;amp;projectId=black-history-and-culture&amp;amp;v.filter=items&quot;&gt;5,000+ items&lt;/a&gt; and more than &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/browse/?q.openId=8129907598665562501&amp;amp;projectId=black-history-and-culture&amp;amp;v.filter=exhibits&quot;&gt;80 curated exhibits&lt;/a&gt;. It includes new Street View imagery and three &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/edu/expeditions/&quot;&gt;Google Expeditions&lt;/a&gt;, including an exploration of the resurgence of Jazz in New Orleans with Irvin Mayfield and Soledad O’Brien. You can see a 360 degree YouTube video made in conjunction with that Expedition here:&lt;br /&gt;&lt;iframe allowfullscreen=&quot;&quot; frameborder=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;360&quot; src=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/embed/dFq9wbrV-v0&quot; width=&quot;640&quot;&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;&lt;br /&gt;In &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/collection/baltimore-museum-of-art?projectId=black-history-and-culture&quot;&gt;The Baltimore Museum of Art&lt;/a&gt;’s exhibition “&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/exhibit/questioning-the-canon/HQLiHC1bTnB0Kg?projectId=black-history-and-culture&quot;&gt;Questioning the Canon&lt;/a&gt;,” you can see Mickalene Thomas’s &lt;i&gt;Le dejeuner sur l&#39;herbe: Les Trois Femmes Noires&lt;/i&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/compare/?item1=twELHYoc3ID_VA&amp;amp;item2=rQEufReZTVODGQ&quot;&gt;compare&lt;/a&gt; it side-by-side with the Manet original to see the ways Thomas has subverted the subject-matter of this canonical white European work.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-w9ugmNrJlok/Vq7wboBfneI/AAAAAAAAR0M/1BV9xCrfSRc/s1600/Screen%2BShot%2B2016-01-29%2Bat%2B11.53.57%2BAM.png&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;256&quot; src=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-w9ugmNrJlok/Vq7wboBfneI/AAAAAAAAR0M/1BV9xCrfSRc/s640/Screen%2BShot%2B2016-01-29%2Bat%2B11.53.57%2BAM.png&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;You can trace along the paths of history by reading &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/asset-viewer/frederick-douglass-to-his-former-master-hugh-auld/swGYJeBKLMrKkQ?projectId=black-history-and-culture&quot;&gt;Frederick Douglass’ letter&lt;/a&gt; to his former master, and read the original manuscripts of Dr. King’s ”&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/asset-viewer/speech-i-have-a-dream/TwEppFBecI2Tpg?projectId=black-history-and-culture&amp;amp;l.expanded-id=7gH7Gbbi1a4Zbg&quot;&gt;I Have a Dream&lt;/a&gt;” and  “&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/asset-viewer/speech-i-ve-been-to-the-mountaintop/awHIyIKypGJDVQ?projectId=black-history-and-culture&amp;amp;l.expanded-id=LgH0gwjOh0d7TA&quot;&gt;I’ve Been to the Mountaintop&lt;/a&gt;” speeches. Absorb Dr. King’s &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/asset-viewer/letter-from-mlk-to-coretta-scott-king/NQF6fTotFKcJ9Q?projectId=black-history-and-culture&amp;amp;l.expanded-id=NwE0l9zzDQcIOg&quot;&gt;personal letter to wife Coretta Scott King&lt;/a&gt; at the beginning of his four-month prison term for non-violent protest, then cut to photographs documenting his momentous &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/asset-viewer/president-lyndon-b-johnson-moves-to-shake-hands-with-dr-martin-luther-king-while-others-look-on/swHLZbBEG4wXXQ?projectId=black-history-and-culture&quot;&gt;first handshake at the White House&lt;/a&gt; with President Lyndon B. Johnson.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-GQmKUucIo2M/Vq7wbvb29_I/AAAAAAAAR0I/tC4JD65XndA/s1600/Screenshot%2B2016-01-29%2Bat%2B4.02.49%2BPM.png&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;393&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-GQmKUucIo2M/Vq7wbvb29_I/AAAAAAAAR0I/tC4JD65XndA/s640/Screenshot%2B2016-01-29%2Bat%2B4.02.49%2BPM.png&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Collecting these works into one place provides unprecedented access to a vital part of history that is too often forgotten. By comparing works of art and texts of speeches to find commonalities and distinctions, we can also build on the past to inspire ourselves and others. And while today is the first day of Black History Month, the work of remembering our history is necessary year round—which is why these records will be there on the Cultural Institute for generations to come.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;byline-author&quot;&gt;Posted by Valeisha Butterfield Jones, Head of Black Community Engagement&lt;/span&gt;  &lt;span data-about-syndication=&quot;&quot; style=&quot;display: none; font-size: 0; line-height: 0; max-height: 0; overflow: hidden;&quot;&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-image&quot;&gt;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-GQmKUucIo2M/Vq7wbvb29_I/AAAAAAAAR0I/tC4JD65XndA/s1600/Screenshot%2B2016-01-29%2Bat%2B4.02.49%2BPM.png&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-name&quot;&gt;Valeisha Butterfield Jones&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-title&quot;&gt;Head of Black Community Engagement&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-team&quot;&gt;AUTHOR TEAM&lt;/span&gt; &lt;/span&gt;</content><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/5996013638035979764'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/5996013638035979764'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2016/02/preserving-celebrating-black-history.html' title='Preserving and celebrating Black history, arts and culture'/><author><name>Google Blogs</name><uri>https://plus.google.com/112374322230920073195</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//lh3.googleusercontent.com/-SMZmHeOVbFs/AAAAAAAAAAI/AAAAAAAAR7c/esUAZEvmr9M/s512-c/photo.jpg'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://img.youtube.com/vi/dFq9wbrV-v0/default.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentSource" value="1"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentModerationMode" value="FILTERED_POSTMOD"/></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-10861780.post-4335412002226383829</id><published>2016-01-27T10:01:00.002-08:00</published><updated>2016-01-27T10:01:42.119-08:00</updated><title type='text'>AlphaGo: using machine learning to master the ancient game of Go</title><content type='html'>The game of &lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Go_(game)&quot;&gt;Go&lt;/a&gt; originated in China more than 2,500 years ago. &lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confucius&quot;&gt;Confucius&lt;/a&gt; wrote about the game, and it is considered one of the &lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four_arts&quot;&gt;four essential arts&lt;/a&gt; required of any true Chinese scholar. &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=irGmbwqqUNs&quot;&gt;Played by more than 40 million people worldwide&lt;/a&gt;, the rules of the game are simple: Players take turns to place black or white stones on a board, trying to capture the opponent&#39;s stones or surround empty space to make points of territory. The game is played primarily through intuition and feel, and because of its beauty, subtlety and intellectual depth it has captured the human imagination for centuries.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;But as simple as the rules are, Go is a game of profound complexity. There are 1,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 possible positions—that’s more than the number of atoms in the universe, and more than a googol times larger than chess.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;This complexity is what makes Go hard for computers to play, and therefore an irresistible challenge to artificial intelligence (AI) researchers, who use games as a testing ground to invent smart, flexible algorithms that can tackle problems, sometimes in ways similar to humans. The first game mastered by a computer was &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.pong-story.com/1952.htm&quot;&gt;noughts and crosses&lt;/a&gt; (also known as tic-tac-toe) in 1952. Then fell &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.aaai.org/ojs/index.php/aimagazine/article/viewFile/1208/1109&quot;&gt;checkers&lt;/a&gt; in 1994. In 1997 Deep Blue famously beat Garry Kasparov at &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0004370201001291/pdf?md5=a843a5b1c9049457e0d3adb68117b4ed&amp;amp;pid=1-s2.0-S0004370201001291-main.pdf&quot;&gt;chess&lt;/a&gt;. It’s not limited to board games either—IBM&#39;s &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.aaai.org/ojs/index.php/aimagazine/article/download/2303/2165&quot;&gt;Watson&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;[PDF] bested two champions at Jeopardy in 2011, and &lt;a href=&quot;http://googleresearch.blogspot.com/2015/02/from-pixels-to-actions-human-level.html&quot;&gt;in 2014 our own algorithms learned to play dozens of Atari games&lt;/a&gt; just from the &lt;a href=&quot;https://storage.googleapis.com/deepmind-data/assets/papers/DeepMindNature14236Paper.pdf&quot;&gt;raw pixel inputs&lt;/a&gt;. But to date, Go has thwarted AI researchers; computers still only play Go as well as amateurs. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Traditional AI methods—which construct a &lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Search_tree&quot;&gt;search tree&lt;/a&gt; over all possible positions—don’t have a chance in Go. So when we set out to crack Go, we took a different approach. We built a system, AlphaGo, that combines an &lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monte_Carlo_tree_search&quot;&gt;advanced tree search&lt;/a&gt; with &lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_learning#Deep_neural_networks&quot;&gt;deep neural networks&lt;/a&gt;. These neural networks take a description of the Go board as an input and process it through 12 different network layers containing millions of neuron-like connections.  One neural network, the “policy network,” selects the next move to play. The other neural network, the “value network,” predicts the winner of the game. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;We trained the neural networks on 30 million moves from games played by human experts, until it could predict the human move 57 percent of the time (the previous record before AlphaGo was &lt;a href=&quot;http://arxiv.org/pdf/1412.3409&quot;&gt;44 percent&lt;/a&gt;). But our goal is to beat the best human players, not just mimic them. To do this, AlphaGo learned to discover new strategies for itself, by playing thousands of games between its neural networks, and adjusting the connections using a trial-and-error process known as &lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning&quot;&gt;reinforcement learning&lt;/a&gt;. Of course, all of this requires a huge amount of computing power, so we made extensive use of &lt;a href=&quot;https://cloud.google.com/&quot;&gt;Google Cloud Platform&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;After all that training it was time to put AlphaGo to the test. First, we held a tournament between AlphaGo and the other top programs at the forefront of computer Go. AlphaGo won all but one of its 500 games against these programs. So the next step was to invite the reigning three-time European Go champion Fan Hui—an elite professional player who has devoted his life to Go since the age of 12—to our London office for a challenge match. In a closed-doors match last October, AlphaGo won by 5 games to 0. It was the first time a computer program has ever beaten a professional Go player. You can find out more in our paper, which was published in &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v529/n7587/full/nature16961.html&quot;&gt;Nature&lt;/a&gt; today. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;iframe allowfullscreen=&quot;&quot; frameborder=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;360&quot; src=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/embed/SUbqykXVx0A&quot; width=&quot;640&quot;&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;&lt;br /&gt;What’s next? In March, AlphaGo will face its ultimate challenge: a five-game challenge match in Seoul against the legendary &lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Se-dol&quot;&gt;Lee Sedol&lt;/a&gt;—the top Go player in the world over the past decade. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;We are thrilled to have mastered Go and thus achieved one of the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.wired.com/2014/05/the-world-of-computer-go/&quot;&gt;grand challenges of AI&lt;/a&gt;. However, the most significant aspect of all this for us is that AlphaGo isn’t just an &lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expert_system&quot;&gt;“expert” system&lt;/a&gt; built with hand-crafted rules; instead it uses general machine learning techniques to figure out for itself how to win at Go. While games are the perfect platform for developing and testing AI algorithms quickly and efficiently, ultimately we want to apply these techniques to important real-world problems. Because the methods we’ve used are general-purpose, our hope is that one day they could be extended to help us address some of society’s toughest and most pressing problems, from climate modelling to complex disease analysis. We’re excited to see what we can use this technology to tackle next!&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;byline-author&quot;&gt;Posted by Demis Hassabis, Google DeepMind&lt;/span&gt;  &lt;span data-about-syndication=&quot;&quot; style=&quot;display: none; font-size: 0; line-height: 0; max-height: 0; overflow: hidden;&quot;&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-image&quot;&gt;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-UM6zXm-cXW4/VqkFrP32nlI/AAAAAAAARzw/HmxeOsYvvqk/s1600/Go-game_hero.jpg&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-name&quot;&gt;Demis Hassabis&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;post-author-team&quot;&gt;Google DeepMind&lt;/span&gt; &lt;/span&gt;</content><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/4335412002226383829'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/4335412002226383829'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2016/01/alphago-machine-learning-game-go.html' title='AlphaGo: using machine learning to master the ancient game of Go'/><author><name>Google Blogs</name><uri>https://plus.google.com/112374322230920073195</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//lh3.googleusercontent.com/-SMZmHeOVbFs/AAAAAAAAAAI/AAAAAAAAR7c/esUAZEvmr9M/s512-c/photo.jpg'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://img.youtube.com/vi/SUbqykXVx0A/default.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentSource" value="1"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentModerationMode" value="FILTERED_POSTMOD"/></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-10861780.post-6738691810098357399</id><published>2016-01-27T08:00:00.000-08:00</published><updated>2016-01-27T10:15:15.693-08:00</updated><category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="cardboard"/><title type='text'>(Un)folding a virtual journey with Google Cardboard</title><content type='html'>A year and a half ago we introduced Google Cardboard, a simple cardboard viewer that anyone can use to experience mobile virtual reality (VR). With just Cardboard and the smartphone in your pocket, you can travel to &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xPhdLz2Ebfw&quot;&gt;faraway&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/nytvr/&quot;&gt;places&lt;/a&gt; and visit &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/googlecardboard/status/677180816561012736&quot;&gt;imagined&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nGUab4jwbwg&quot;&gt;worlds&lt;/a&gt;. Since then everyone from &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/googlecardboard/status/677360846260031489&quot;&gt;droid lovers&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/nms/status/663475106946027520&quot;&gt;Sunday edition subscribers&lt;/a&gt;, to &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yyca0sHKkJ8&quot;&gt;big kids&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;and &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SiVWhYZUjpQ&quot;&gt;grandmas&lt;/a&gt; have been able to enjoy VR—often for the very first time. Here&#39;s a look at where we are, 19 months in:&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;1. 5 million Cardboard fans have joined the fold.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-6RqvrK4HuVQ/Vqjf2E6SlkI/AAAAAAAARy4/wzyIz0-LQmQ/s1600/VR1.png&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;360&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-6RqvrK4HuVQ/Vqjf2E6SlkI/AAAAAAAARy4/wzyIz0-LQmQ/s640/VR1.png&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;2. In just the past two months (October-December), you launched into 10 million more immersive app experiences:&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-TPRBpJDrNBs/Vqjf2BxhXBI/AAAAAAAARy8/eMEynMmZdVA/s1600/VR2.png&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;360&quot; src=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-TPRBpJDrNBs/Vqjf2BxhXBI/AAAAAAAARy8/eMEynMmZdVA/s640/VR2.png&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;3. Out of 1,000+ &lt;a href=&quot;https://play.google.com/store/apps/collection/promotion_3001527_cardboard_apps&quot;&gt;Cardboard apps&lt;/a&gt; on Google Play, &lt;a href=&quot;https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.dejobaangames.caaaaardboard&quot;&gt;one of your favorites&lt;/a&gt; got you screaming “aaaaaaahwsome,” while &lt;a href=&quot;https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.shakingearthdigital.vrsecardboard&quot;&gt;another&lt;/a&gt; “gave you goosebumps.”&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-7O0NwncQ4x4/Vqjf2MEXN1I/AAAAAAAARy0/qiSZ4CJRrUo/s1600/VR3.png&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;360&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-7O0NwncQ4x4/Vqjf2MEXN1I/AAAAAAAARy0/qiSZ4CJRrUo/s640/VR3.png&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;4. You teleported to places far and wide, right from the &lt;a href=&quot;http://youtube-global.blogspot.com/2015/11/youtube-presses-play-on-virtual-reality.html&quot;&gt;comfort of YouTube&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-uoeUSBYr0xw/Vqjf24fosbI/AAAAAAAARzA/reQcTYRURt8/s1600/VR4.png&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;360&quot; src=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-uoeUSBYr0xw/Vqjf24fosbI/AAAAAAAARzA/reQcTYRURt8/s640/VR4.png&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;5. Since we launched &lt;a href=&quot;https://googleblog.blogspot.com/2015/12/step-inside-your-photos-with-cardboard.html&quot;&gt;Cardboard Camera&lt;/a&gt; in December, you’ve captured more than 750,000 VR photos, letting you relive your favorite moments anytime, from anywhere.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-01Z1btTCbQk/Vqjf3UM8ArI/AAAAAAAARzM/5ie4k6y5rrE/s1600/VR5.png&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;360&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-01Z1btTCbQk/Vqjf3UM8ArI/AAAAAAAARzM/5ie4k6y5rrE/s640/VR5.png&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;6. Students around the world have taken VR field trips to the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=98U2jdk8OGI&quot;&gt;White House&lt;/a&gt;, the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LMomKIt1uWA&quot;&gt;Republic of Congo&lt;/a&gt;, and 150 other places around the globe with &lt;a href=&quot;https://googleblog.blogspot.com/2015/09/bring-virtual-reality-field-trips-to.html&quot;&gt;Expeditions&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-_U7bqeJSKAE/Vqjf3msE_wI/AAAAAAAARzU/1LFI1cjhF0Y/s1600/VR6.png&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;360&quot; src=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-_U7bqeJSKAE/Vqjf3msE_wI/AAAAAAAARzU/1LFI1cjhF0Y/s640/VR6.png&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;While you&#39;ve been traveling the world and beyond with Cardboard, we&#39;ve been on a journey, too. Keep your eyes peeled for more projects that bring creative, entertaining and educational experiences to mobile VR.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;byline-author&quot;&gt;Posted by Clay Bavor, VP Virtual Reality&lt;/span&gt;  &lt;span data-about-syndication=&quot;&quot; style=&quot;display: none; font-size: 0; line-height: 0; max-height: 0; overflow: hidden;&quot;&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-image&quot;&gt;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-2lf4cAt9Xoo/VqkFrHZ5xxI/AAAAAAAARzs/E8ZK8l4EPo8/s1600/Google-Cardboard_hero.jpg&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-name&quot;&gt;Clay Bavor&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-title&quot;&gt;VP&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-team&quot;&gt;Virtual Reality&lt;/span&gt; &lt;/span&gt;</content><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/6738691810098357399'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/6738691810098357399'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2016/01/unfolding-virtual-journey-cardboard.html' title='(Un)folding a virtual journey with Google Cardboard'/><author><name>Google Blogs</name><uri>https://plus.google.com/112374322230920073195</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//lh3.googleusercontent.com/-SMZmHeOVbFs/AAAAAAAAAAI/AAAAAAAAR7c/esUAZEvmr9M/s512-c/photo.jpg'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-6RqvrK4HuVQ/Vqjf2E6SlkI/AAAAAAAARy4/wzyIz0-LQmQ/s72-c/VR1.png" height="72" width="72"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentSource" value="1"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentModerationMode" value="FILTERED_POSTMOD"/></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-10861780.post-6986215603708984386</id><published>2016-01-26T08:30:00.000-08:00</published><updated>2016-01-26T15:42:17.588-08:00</updated><category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="politics"/><title type='text'>New ways to stay informed about presidential politics</title><content type='html'>In just two days, Americans will tune in for the final Republican debate before the 2016 primary season officially kicks off in Iowa, and we’re &lt;a href=&quot;http://googlepolitics.blogspot.com/2016/01/google-and-fox-news-channel-present.html&quot;&gt;teaming up with Fox News Channel&lt;/a&gt; to make sure every citizen can get the most out of it. To help people get informed before heading to the polls, we’re integrating three new components into the debate: a way to hear directly from candidates on Google; real-time Google Trends data; and questions from some of YouTube’s most prominent voices. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Hear from candidates directly, right on Google&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Political search interest spikes 440 percent on average during live televised debates as people turn to the web to learn more about the candidates and their platforms. Now people will have a new way to hear directly from candidates themselves, in real-time—right in Google Search results. This experimental feature helps voters make more informed choices, and levels the playing field for candidates to share ideas and positions on issues they may not have had a chance to address during the debate. By publishing long-form text, photos and videos throughout the debate, campaigns can now give extended responses, answer questions they didn’t get a chance to on stage, and rebut their opponents. As soon as the first debate begins at 7 p.m. ET on Thursday, search “Fox News debate” to find campaign responses.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-2u2MdgCeRfo/VqedCWwwmHI/AAAAAAAARyQ/AKX7cLGJQzU/s1600/pasted%2Bimage%2B0.png&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;348&quot; src=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-2u2MdgCeRfo/VqedCWwwmHI/AAAAAAAARyQ/AKX7cLGJQzU/s640/pasted%2Bimage%2B0.png&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;b&gt;Dig into issues with Google Trends &lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Throughout the debate, we’ll also spotlight key insights from &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/trends/story/US_cu_5NL_ZVIBAABJNM_en&quot;&gt;Google Trends&lt;/a&gt; that offer interesting insights about the candidates, issues, and debate topics—anything from &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/GoogleTrends/status/689446079436234752?lang=en&quot;&gt;questions asked about key issues&lt;/a&gt; to &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/GoogleTrends/status/689791891555115008?lang=en&quot;&gt;trending terms&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/GoogleTrends/status/687867238708285440?lang=en&quot;&gt;rankings&lt;/a&gt; like the below minute-by-minute view of which candidate was searched most during the last debate.  &lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-Hl8yhanW8gA/VqedCgntrYI/AAAAAAAARyM/PzzYfM-6q7E/s1600/2016-01-25.gif&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-Hl8yhanW8gA/VqedCgntrYI/AAAAAAAARyM/PzzYfM-6q7E/s1600/2016-01-25.gif&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;You’ll also be able to answer polling questions about the issues that matter to you directly on Google Search when you search “Fox News debate.” Fox News will cover responses to these questions on air after the debate. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Watch YouTube creators engage with the candidates&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Finally, three prominent YouTube creators—&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/NabelaNoor&quot;&gt;Nabela Noor&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/SoldierKnowsBest&quot;&gt;Mark Watson&lt;/a&gt;, and &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/dulcecandy&quot;&gt;Dulce Candy&lt;/a&gt;—will join the moderators in the debate to ask the candidates a question on an issue that matters to them and their communities. Bringing new voices from YouTube to political debates is something we’ve been doing since the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7Pw-oPjSeb4&quot;&gt;2008 election&lt;/a&gt;, and it can lead to &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PuRLwReqTxw&quot;&gt;personal&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YHl1aGyPm5s&quot;&gt;powerful&lt;/a&gt; interactions between candidates and voters.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;iframe allowfullscreen=&quot;&quot; frameborder=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;360&quot; src=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/embed/EjPzcPJ-8hg&quot; width=&quot;640&quot;&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The debate begins at 7 p.m. ET on Thursday, with the prime time debate starting at 9 p.m. ET. So tune in to Fox News Channel to learn more about your presidential candidates on Google!&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;byline-author&quot;&gt;Posted by Danielle Bowers, Google News Lab &lt;/span&gt;  &lt;span data-about-syndication=&quot;&quot; style=&quot;display: none; font-size: 0; line-height: 0; max-height: 0; overflow: hidden;&quot;&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-image&quot;&gt;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-0qiDZwEYmuQ/VqgEMMg61mI/AAAAAAAARyk/rjVquq9izfE/s1600/GOP-debate_hero.jpg&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-name&quot;&gt;Danielle Bowers &lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-team&quot;&gt;Google News Lab&lt;/span&gt; &lt;/span&gt;</content><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/6986215603708984386'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/6986215603708984386'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2016/01/republican-debate-presidential-politics.html' title='New ways to stay informed about presidential politics'/><author><name>Google Blogs</name><uri>https://plus.google.com/112374322230920073195</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//lh3.googleusercontent.com/-SMZmHeOVbFs/AAAAAAAAAAI/AAAAAAAAR7c/esUAZEvmr9M/s512-c/photo.jpg'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-2u2MdgCeRfo/VqedCWwwmHI/AAAAAAAARyQ/AKX7cLGJQzU/s72-c/pasted%2Bimage%2B0.png" height="72" width="72"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentSource" value="1"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentModerationMode" value="FILTERED_POSTMOD"/></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-10861780.post-5136351009141275169</id><published>2016-01-25T05:00:00.000-08:00</published><updated>2016-01-25T16:12:42.546-08:00</updated><title type='text'>Helping refugees access education and information </title><content type='html'>Ahmed is an economics student from Aleppo in Syria. Last year he was forced to leave his hometown because of the war that has forced millions of his compatriots out of their country. He left his family and his studies—everything—behind to find a better future in Europe. Now safe in Berlin, his dream is to continue his studies and eventually become a teacher at a university in Germany.   &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;As they make it through a dangerous journey, the first thing refugees need is to find shelter, food and access to care. But soon enough, they have to learn the local language, acquire skills to work in a new country, and figure out a way to continue their studies—all in an effort to reclaim and reconnect with the lives they had before. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Last fall, we &lt;a href=&quot;https://googleblog.blogspot.co.uk/2015/10/update-response-refugee-migrants.html&quot;&gt;shared&lt;/a&gt; how we’re supporting organizations on the frontline of providing essential humanitarian relief support. But we also wanted to do something to help with refugees’ long-term challenges, such as the need for access to information and education. So today, we’re making a $5.3 million Google.org grant to support the launch of Project Reconnect, a program by &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nethope.org/&quot;&gt;NetHope&lt;/a&gt; to equip nonprofits working with refugees in Germany with Chromebooks, in order to facilitate easier access to education for refugees like Ahmed. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-KrDwSP4AfEM/VqXHD7E_oqI/AAAAAAAARxs/0CwvX0e0eX8/s1600/reconnect.png&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;400&quot; src=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-KrDwSP4AfEM/VqXHD7E_oqI/AAAAAAAARxs/0CwvX0e0eX8/s400/reconnect.png&quot; width=&quot;400&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Chromebooks have proven to be a good fit for education purposes. They can be easily set up to run education or language learning apps. They’re automatically kept up to date with the latest features, apps and virus protection. And they can be configured and managed by a central administrator (in this case the nonprofits) to offer relevant programs, content and materials depending on the situation. For example, they can run an educational game for children, a language course for younger adults or even feature information about the asylum application process on a pre-installed homepage. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Nonprofits can apply today on &lt;a href=&quot;http://reconnect.nethope.org/&quot;&gt;this website&lt;/a&gt;. Many organizations and their staff are doing incredible work in very difficult circumstances to help with this crisis. We hope that by supporting these nonprofits, we can help people like Ahmed on the next step of their journey.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;byline-author&quot;&gt;Posted by Jacquelline Fuller, Director of Google.org&lt;/span&gt;  &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span data-about-syndication=&quot;&quot; style=&quot;display: none; font-size: 0; line-height: 0; max-height: 0; overflow: hidden;&quot;&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-image&quot;&gt;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-NyO22rEaB6c/Vqa50axfoMI/AAAAAAAARx8/DuUaNLtwFT0/s1600/Reconnect_hero.jpg&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-name&quot;&gt;Jacquelline Fuller&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-title&quot;&gt;Director&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-team&quot;&gt;Google.org&lt;/span&gt; &lt;/span&gt;</content><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/5136351009141275169'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/5136351009141275169'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2016/01/refugees-education-chromebooks.html' title='Helping refugees access education and information '/><author><name>Google Blogs</name><uri>https://plus.google.com/112374322230920073195</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//lh3.googleusercontent.com/-SMZmHeOVbFs/AAAAAAAAAAI/AAAAAAAAR7c/esUAZEvmr9M/s512-c/photo.jpg'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-KrDwSP4AfEM/VqXHD7E_oqI/AAAAAAAARxs/0CwvX0e0eX8/s72-c/reconnect.png" height="72" width="72"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentSource" value="1"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentModerationMode" value="FILTERED_POSTMOD"/></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-10861780.post-4977724805422994379</id><published>2016-01-21T06:00:00.000-08:00</published><updated>2016-01-22T11:31:25.531-08:00</updated><title type='text'>How we fought bad ads in 2015</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-5Qsch6JIUGA/VqKDAgZJDyI/AAAAAAAARw0/ed3JFm5kujQ/s1600/Better_Ads_Report_2015_1600_Intro_header.png&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;200&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-5Qsch6JIUGA/VqKDAgZJDyI/AAAAAAAARw0/ed3JFm5kujQ/s640/Better_Ads_Report_2015_1600_Intro_header.png&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;When ads are good, they connect you to products or services you’re interested in and make it easier to get stuff you want. They also keep a lot of what you love about the web—like news sites or mobile apps—free.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;But some ads are just plain bad—like ads that carry malware, cover up content you’re trying to see, or promote fake goods. Bad ads can ruin your entire online experience, a problem we take very seriously. That’s why we have a strict set of &lt;a href=&quot;https://support.google.com/adwordspolicy/answer/6008942?hl=en&quot;&gt;policies&lt;/a&gt; for the kinds of ads businesses can run with Google—and why we’ve invested in sophisticated technology and a global team of 1,000+ people dedicated to fighting bad ads. Last year alone we disabled more than 780 million ads for violating our policies—a number that&#39;s increased over the years thanks to new protections we&#39;ve put in place. If you spent one second looking at each of these ads, it’d take you nearly 25 years to see them all!&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Here are some of the top areas we focused on in our fight against bad ads in 2015:&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Busting bad ads&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Some bad ads, like those for products that falsely claim to help with weight loss, mislead people. Others help fraudsters carry out scams, like those that lead to “phishing” sites that trick people into handing over personal information. Through a combination of computer algorithms and people at Google reviewing ads, we’re able to block the vast majority of these bad ads before they ever get shown. Here are some types of bad ads we busted in 2015:&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-OIfS_8_NrC4/VqKDAGp6BAI/AAAAAAAARwo/p_oluxig208/s1600/Better_Ads_Report_2015_1600_Busting_bad_ads.png&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;200&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-OIfS_8_NrC4/VqKDAGp6BAI/AAAAAAAARwo/p_oluxig208/s640/Better_Ads_Report_2015_1600_Busting_bad_ads.png&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: small;&quot;&gt;Counterfeiters&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: small;&quot;&gt;We suspended more than 10,000 sites and 18,000 accounts for attempting to sell counterfeit goods (like imitation designer watches). &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: small;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;b&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: small;&quot;&gt;Pharmaceuticals&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: small;&quot;&gt;We blocked more than 12.5 million ads that violated our healthcare and medicines policy, such as ads for pharmaceuticals that weren’t approved for use or that made misleading claims to be as effective as prescription drugs. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: small;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;b&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: small;&quot;&gt;Weight loss scams&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: small;&quot;&gt;Weight loss scams, like ads for supplements promising impossible-to-achieve weight loss without diet or exercise, were one of the top user complaints in 2015. We responded by suspending more than 30,000 sites for misleading claims.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: small;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;b&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: small;&quot;&gt;Phishing&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: small;&quot;&gt;In 2015, we stepped up our efforts to fight &lt;a href=&quot;https://support.google.com/websearch/answer/106318?hl=en&quot;&gt;phishing sites&lt;/a&gt;, blocking nearly 7,000 sites as a result.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: small;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/b&gt; &lt;b&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: small;&quot;&gt;Unwanted software&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: small;&quot;&gt;Unwanted software can slow your devices down or unexpectedly change your homepage and keep you from changing it back. With powerful new protections, we disabled more than 10,000 sites offering &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/about/company/unwanted-software-policy.html&quot;&gt;unwanted software&lt;/a&gt;, and reduced unwanted downloads via Google ads by more than 99 percent.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-2rhewq4YOJw/VqKDBCJulII/AAAAAAAARxA/F3orjvLeQYA/s1600/Better_Ads_Report_2015_1600_Unwanted_software.png&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;160&quot; src=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-2rhewq4YOJw/VqKDBCJulII/AAAAAAAARxA/F3orjvLeQYA/s640/Better_Ads_Report_2015_1600_Unwanted_software.png&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: small;&quot;&gt;Trick to click&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: small;&quot;&gt;We got even tougher on ads that mislead or trick people into interacting with them—like ads designed to look like system warnings from your computer. In 2015 alone we rejected more than 17 million.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-wwP-3idNO-E/VqKDBCdZ9pI/AAAAAAAARw8/iNGUOju4vXI/s1600/Better_Ads_Report_2015_1600_Trick_to_click.png&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;160&quot; src=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-wwP-3idNO-E/VqKDBCdZ9pI/AAAAAAAARw8/iNGUOju4vXI/s640/Better_Ads_Report_2015_1600_Trick_to_click.png&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;b&gt;Creating a better experience&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Sometimes even ads that offer helpful and relevant information behave in ways that can be really annoying—covering up what you’re trying to see or sending you to an advertiser’s site when you didn’t intend to go there. In 2015, we disabled or banned the worst offenders. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-SDU9Kyu89Mg/VqKDABzpWLI/AAAAAAAARws/pv803XyESps/s1600/Better_Ads_Report_2015_1600_Creating_a_better_experience.png&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;200&quot; src=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-SDU9Kyu89Mg/VqKDABzpWLI/AAAAAAAARws/pv803XyESps/s640/Better_Ads_Report_2015_1600_Creating_a_better_experience.png&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: small;&quot;&gt;Accidental mobile clicks&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: small;&quot;&gt;We’ve all been there. You’re swiping through a slideshow of the best moments from the Presidential debate when an ad redirects you even though you didn’t mean to click on it. We’re working to end that. We&#39;ve developed technology to determine when clicks on mobile ads are accidental. Instead of sending you off to an advertiser page you didn&#39;t mean to visit, we let you continue enjoying your slideshow (and the advertiser doesn&#39;t get charged).&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: small;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;b&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: small;&quot;&gt;Bad sites and apps&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: small;&quot;&gt;In 2015, we stopped showing ads on more than 25,000 mobile apps because the developers didn’t follow our policies. More than two-thirds of these violations were for practices like mobile ads placed very close to buttons, causing someone to accidentally click the ad. There are also some sites and apps that we choose not to work with because they don’t follow our policies. We also reject applications from sites and mobile apps that want to show Google ads but don&#39;t follow our policies. In 2015 alone, we rejected more than 1.4 million applications.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;Putting you in control&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;We also give you tools to control the type of ads you see. You can always &lt;a href=&quot;https://support.google.com/adwords/troubleshooter/4578507?rd=1&quot;&gt;let us know&lt;/a&gt; when you believe an ad might be violating our policies.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: small;&quot;&gt;Mute This Ad&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: small;&quot;&gt;Maybe you’ve just seen way too many car ads recently. “&lt;a href=&quot;https://privacy.google.com/about-ads.html?utm_source=ogb-blog&amp;amp;utm_medium=blog-pr&amp;amp;utm_campaign=better-ads-blog#take-control-of-your-google-ads-experience&quot;&gt;Mute This Ad&lt;/a&gt;” lets you click an “X” at the top on many of the ads we show and Google will stop showing you that ad and others like it from that advertiser. You can also tell us why. The 4+ billion pieces of feedback we received in 2015 are helping us show better ads and shape our policies.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-WM0bZCUAbcg/VqKDA0vzMcI/AAAAAAAARw4/pbXksAboLvU/s1600/Better_Ads_Report_2015_1600_Mute_This_Ad.png&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;160&quot; src=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-WM0bZCUAbcg/VqKDA0vzMcI/AAAAAAAARw4/pbXksAboLvU/s640/Better_Ads_Report_2015_1600_Mute_This_Ad.png&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: small;&quot;&gt;Ads Settings&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: small;&quot;&gt;In 2015, we rolled out a new design for our &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/settings/u/0/ads/authenticated?hl=en&quot;&gt;Ads Settings&lt;/a&gt; where you can manage your ads experience. You can update your interests to make the ads you see more relevant, or block specific advertisers all together.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-G_1KpWCAOpk/VqKDAJG2ypI/AAAAAAAARww/WmYIeLeZuzk/s1600/Better_Ads_Report_2015_1600_Ad_settings.png&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;160&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-G_1KpWCAOpk/VqKDAJG2ypI/AAAAAAAARww/WmYIeLeZuzk/s640/Better_Ads_Report_2015_1600_Ad_settings.png&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;b&gt;Looking ahead to 2016&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;We’re always updating our technology and our policies based on your feedback—and working to stay one step ahead of the fraudsters. In 2016, we’re planning updates like further restricting what can be advertised as effective for weight loss, and adding new protections against malware and bots. We want to make sure all the ads you see are helpful and welcome and we’ll keep fighting to make that a reality.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;byline-author&quot;&gt;Posted by Sridhar Ramaswamy, SVP, Ads &amp;amp; Commerce&lt;/span&gt; &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span data-about-syndication=&quot;&quot; style=&quot;display: none; font-size: 0; line-height: 0; max-height: 0; overflow: hidden;&quot;&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-image&quot;&gt;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-CzH9B5r8W-c/VqE-GbdMYpI/AAAAAAAARwY/RpZ4_RPDtEM/s1600/Blog_Better_Ads_Report_Hero-17.png&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-name&quot;&gt;Sridhar Ramaswamy&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-title&quot;&gt;Senior Vice President&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-team&quot;&gt;Ads &amp;amp; Commerce&lt;/span&gt; &lt;/span&gt;</content><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/4977724805422994379'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/4977724805422994379'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2016/01/better-ads-report.html' title='How we fought bad ads in 2015'/><author><name>Google Blogs</name><uri>https://plus.google.com/112374322230920073195</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//lh3.googleusercontent.com/-SMZmHeOVbFs/AAAAAAAAAAI/AAAAAAAAR7c/esUAZEvmr9M/s512-c/photo.jpg'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-5Qsch6JIUGA/VqKDAgZJDyI/AAAAAAAARw0/ed3JFm5kujQ/s72-c/Better_Ads_Report_2015_1600_Intro_header.png" height="72" width="72"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentSource" value="1"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentModerationMode" value="FILTERED_POSTMOD"/></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-10861780.post-1516669129103528265</id><published>2016-01-21T01:00:00.000-08:00</published><updated>2016-01-21T01:00:02.735-08:00</updated><category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="maps and earth"/><title type='text'>Reach new heights with Street View of Mont Blanc in Google Maps</title><content type='html'>Declared the “monarch of mountains” by Lord Byron, the &lt;a href=&quot;http://g.co/MontBlanc&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Mont Blanc massif&lt;/a&gt; is shrouded in mystery, rolling clouds and imposing snowfields. One of Europe’s highest peaks, the wild terrain of the famed mountain range is reserved for ardent mountaineers and intrepid explorers. Starting today in Google Maps, you can get an up-close, 360-degree look at the breathtaking beauty of Mont Blanc.
