Following last year’s first-ever vertical imagery collection of El Capitan in California’s &lt;a href=&quot;http://g.co/Yosemite&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Yosemite National Park&lt;/a&gt;, we partnered with world-renowned alpine photographers, skiers, mountaineers, climbers, and runners to collect Street View of Western Europe’s highest peak. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;iframe allowfullscreen=&quot;&quot; class=&quot;YOUTUBE-iframe-video&quot; data-thumbnail-src=&quot;https://i.ytimg.com/vi/I6UGj9aWCnU/0.jpg&quot; frameborder=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;365&quot; src=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/embed/I6UGj9aWCnU?feature=player_embedded&quot; width=&quot;650&quot;&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;By working with legendary adventurers, the Street View team was able to capture the spirit of the massif in a way few witness firsthand. Run on the summit with &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/maps/@45.832617,6.8651793,3a,75y,25.55h,63.47t/data=!3m7!1e1!3m5!1s1bdRoq8Vk8EAAAQzzZq2-w!2e0!3e2!7i13312!8i6656&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Kilian Jornet&lt;/a&gt;—he holds the speed record for ascending and descending Mont Blanc in just 4 hours 57 minutes! Ice climb up a serac with record-setting alpine climber &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/maps/@45.8326169,6.8651732,3a,75y,352.42h,86.97t/data=!3m7!1e1!3m5!1s3xbZN2BuOIsAAAQzzZq28g!2e0!3e2!7i13312!8i6656&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Ueli Steck&lt;/a&gt;, or go knee deep in powder alongside 14-time ski mountaineering champion &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/maps/@45.832617,6.8651816,3a,75y,6.8h,65.55t/data=!3m7!1e1!3m5!1siT-yGmgCz2QAAAQzzZq2_g!2e0!3e2!7i13312!8i6656&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Laetitia Roux and famed guide Patrick Gabarrou&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-i70rtEuFhaA/VqAgIN7MI2I/AAAAAAAAEtw/PXgYz379QtA/s1600/Ueli%2BIce%2BClimbing_25MB.gif&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;360&quot; src=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-i70rtEuFhaA/VqAgIN7MI2I/AAAAAAAAEtw/PXgYz379QtA/s640/Ueli%2BIce%2BClimbing_25MB.gif&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;Ueli Steck ice climbing on Mont Blanc&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;You can also join French climbing legend &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/maps/@45.832617,6.8651738,3a,90y,30.7h,101.03t/data=!3m7!1e1!3m5!1symvFH6EWeSoAAAQzzZq28w!2e0!3e2!7i13312!8i6656&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Catherine Destivelle&lt;/a&gt; on the imposing yet beautiful &lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aiguille_du_Midi&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Aiguille du Midi&lt;/a&gt;, the 3842-meter peak near the Mont Blanc. Or, crouch below innovative filmmaker and free skier &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/maps/@45.832617,6.86518,3a,75y,14.22h,83t/data=!3m7!1e1!3m5!1sFHS5EryBLQAAAAQzzZq2_A!2e0!3e2!7i13312!8i6656&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Candide Thovex as he soars through the air&lt;/a&gt; or has fun as only he can—by &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/maps/@45.8326171,6.8651841,3a,75y,20.87h,86.3t/data=!3m7!1e1!3m5!1s40VgLWzy-M8AAAQzzZq3AQ!2e0!3e2!7i13312!8i6656&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;taking his skis from the snow to the grass&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-guDKKRAX_ZI/VqAg5swVoVI/AAAAAAAAEt4/npo4KmqD69Q/s1600/Screen%2BShot%2B2016-01-20%2Bat%2B4.05.32%2BPM.png&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;366&quot; src=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-guDKKRAX_ZI/VqAg5swVoVI/AAAAAAAAEt4/npo4KmqD69Q/s640/Screen%2BShot%2B2016-01-20%2Bat%2B4.05.32%2BPM.png&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/maps/@45.832617,6.8651738,3a,90y,30.7h,101.03t/data=!3m7!1e1!3m5!1symvFH6EWeSoAAAQzzZq28w!2e0!3e2!7i13312!8i6656&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;Catherine Destivelle ascending near the Aiguille du Midi&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-uTerHvgrOsc/VqAinu_FZEI/AAAAAAAAEuE/y01L3wHtsVY/s1600/Shooting%2BKilian%2BSV_BTS%2BStill%2BWOB.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;360&quot; src=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-uTerHvgrOsc/VqAinu_FZEI/AAAAAAAAEuE/y01L3wHtsVY/s640/Shooting%2BKilian%2BSV_BTS%2BStill%2BWOB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://adventure.nationalgeographic.com/adventure/adventurers-of-the-year/2013/renan-ozturk/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Renan Ozturk&lt;/a&gt;, acclaimed cinematographer and National Geographic Adventurer of the Year, alpine photographer &lt;a href=&quot;http://alpineexposures.com/about&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Jonathan Griffith&lt;/a&gt;, and &lt;a href=&quot;http://senderfilms.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Sender Films&lt;/a&gt; joined Google on Mont Blanc as part of the team.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;If reaching the top is what you care about, elite guide &lt;a href=&quot;http://korrapesce.blogspot.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Korra Pesce&lt;/a&gt; joined the troupe by carrying the Street View Trekker up and down the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/maps/@45.8503941,6.8313879,3a,75y,85.04h,85.39t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sedRgGPiZWOxTNOb2LwsRzA!2e0!7i13312!8i6656&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Gouter Route&lt;/a&gt; of Mont Blanc. Click through the Street View to get his first-person perspective of each step to the summit.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-U4qEqovuHvI/VqAjNi20rWI/AAAAAAAAEuM/m_F07EKb_Kk/s1600/Gouter%2BRoute%2BFly%2BUp_25MB.gif&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;360&quot; src=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-U4qEqovuHvI/VqAjNi20rWI/AAAAAAAAEuM/m_F07EKb_Kk/s640/Gouter%2BRoute%2BFly%2BUp_25MB.gif&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;Climb the entire Gouter Route of the Mont Blanc massif&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Unfortunately, Mont Blanc’s glaciers are receding due to climate change. You can &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UMbcntS3APY&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;learn more&lt;/a&gt; about how the rising temperatures are directly affecting the mountain from legendary guide Patrick Gabarrou, who describes the the glacial melt on the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/maps/@45.922158,6.9246975,3a,75y,139.55h,108.53t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sxvr2M88V8hnqad0Qf_m9dA!2e0!7i13312!8i6656&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Mer de Glace&lt;/a&gt;. So this Street View imagery also serves as a digital record of Mont Blanc as it appears today, so future outdoor enthusiasts and scientists can look back at this time capsule to see how the mountain has changed. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-ov08dMzJ6So/VqAj7fw3Z0I/AAAAAAAAEuY/EObgsu5c0kE/s1600/Kilian%2BMB%2BSummit_25MB.gif&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;360&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-ov08dMzJ6So/VqAj7fw3Z0I/AAAAAAAAEuY/EObgsu5c0kE/s640/Kilian%2BMB%2BSummit_25MB.gif&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;Kilian Jornet on the summit of Mont Blanc&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Whether you choose to run up the Mont Blanc with Kilian Jornet or ski down with Laetitia Roux, we hope you enjoy reaching new heights in Europe’s &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.google.com/maps/streetview/#mont-blanc&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;beautiful and endangered mountain range&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;byline-author&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;byline-author&quot;&gt;Posted by Sandy Russell, Project Lead, Mont Blanc Street View&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span data-about-syndication=&quot;&quot; style=&quot;display: none; font-size: 0; line-height: 0; max-height: 0; overflow: hidden;&quot;&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-image&quot;&gt;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-i70rtEuFhaA/VqAgIN7MI2I/AAAAAAAAEtw/PXgYz379QtA/s1600/Ueli%2BIce%2BClimbing_25MB.gif&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-name&quot;&gt;Sandy Russell&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-title&quot;&gt;Project Lead&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-team&quot;&gt;Mont Blanc Street View&lt;/span&gt; &lt;/span&gt;</content><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/1516669129103528265'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/1516669129103528265'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2016/01/street-view-mont-blanc.html' title='Reach new heights with Street View of Mont Blanc in Google Maps'/><author><name>Google Blogs</name><uri>https://plus.google.com/112374322230920073195</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//lh3.googleusercontent.com/-SMZmHeOVbFs/AAAAAAAAAAI/AAAAAAAAR7c/esUAZEvmr9M/s512-c/photo.jpg'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://img.youtube.com/vi/I6UGj9aWCnU/default.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentSource" value="1"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentModerationMode" value="FILTERED_POSTMOD"/></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-10861780.post-4249790036247043749</id><published>2016-01-21T00:01:00.000-08:00</published><updated>2016-01-21T00:01:04.424-08:00</updated><title type='text'>From self-portraits to street art: 1,000 museums at your fingertips </title><content type='html'>The history of art is global. Look at Van Gogh—a Dutchman who spent much of his life in France, and was inspired not only by his contemporaries but also by Japanese artists like &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/u/0/compare/?item1=rwGc5ZWvzXZ0vA&amp;amp;item2=QAFL1JRk6OKiNQ&amp;amp;projectId=art-project&quot;&gt;Hiroshige&lt;/a&gt;. But until recently, the act of enjoying art and culture was limited by geography. Unless you could visit a museum in person, it would be hard for you to appreciate a work, brushstroke by brushstroke. And to fully understand the legacy of someone like Van Gogh, you would have to go from Amsterdam to Chicago to New York to Tokyo to discover and marvel at all of his influences, works and successors.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-qWgCrvkmIqA/VqAtv8miipI/AAAAAAAARuU/uRiMu2oM37w/s1600/NL-%2BStreet%2BArt%2BMuseum%2BAmsterdam%252C%2B%25E2%2580%2598Gogh%2Bvan%2BCruijf%25E2%2580%2599%2Bby%2BUriginal%252C%2Bcompared%2Bto%2Bthe%2Boriginal%2BVan%2BGogh.png&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;333&quot; src=&quot;http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-qWgCrvkmIqA/VqAtv8miipI/AAAAAAAARuU/uRiMu2oM37w/s640/NL-%2BStreet%2BArt%2BMuseum%2BAmsterdam%252C%2B%25E2%2580%2598Gogh%2Bvan%2BCruijf%25E2%2580%2599%2Bby%2BUriginal%252C%2Bcompared%2Bto%2Bthe%2Boriginal%2BVan%2BGogh.png&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/compare/?item1=mwF3N6F_RfJ4_w&amp;amp;item2=MgHboYcuRPjVKw&amp;amp;projectId=street-art&quot;&gt;Left: Van Gogh’s self-portrait (Chicago), right: a street art re-interpretation (Amsterdam)&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;But with the &lt;a href=&quot;http://g.co/ci&quot;&gt;Google Cultural Institute&lt;/a&gt;, it’s all just a few clicks away. Five years ago, &lt;a href=&quot;https://googleblog.blogspot.co.uk/2011/02/explore-museums-and-great-works-of-art.html&quot;&gt;the first 17 museums&lt;/a&gt; brought online a few hundred artworks so that anyone in the world could explore paintings, records and artifacts no matter where they were. Today, on our fifth birthday, the Google Cultural Institute has grown to include the collections of more than 1,000 museums and cultural institutions, with over 60 new ones added just today.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Starting today, you can &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/asset-viewer/solomon-r-guggenheim-museum-interior-streetview/jAHfbv3JGM2KaQ&quot;&gt;descend through the famous rotunda of the Guggenheim museum&lt;/a&gt; in New York—a piece of art in itself—thanks to special aerial Street View imagery, or stroll the grand halls of the world’s heaviest building, the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/exhibit/palace-of-parliament-bucharest-romania/pAJC1Vza0TCILQ?hl=en-GB&quot;&gt;Palace of Parliament in Romania&lt;/a&gt;. View Monet’s famous water lilies &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/asset-viewer/water-lilies/1QFVEEzvlmrVzg&quot;&gt;in super-high “gigapixel” resolution&lt;/a&gt; and zoom in to see his layered brushstrokes—then visit &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/u/0/asset-viewer/water-lilies/swGGZ-T0rwX-og?projectId=art-project&quot;&gt;Monsieur Monet’s real-life garden&lt;/a&gt; to see his inspiration.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;From &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/browse/gigapixel&quot;&gt;“gigapixel” images&lt;/a&gt; to &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/browse/?f.media_type=museumview&amp;amp;s.sort_by=newest&amp;amp;q.openId=8129907598665562501&amp;amp;v.filter=items&quot;&gt;Street View inside museums&lt;/a&gt;, today’s museums, galleries and theatres are turning to technology to help reach new audiences and inspire them with art and culture. And the possibilities keep expanding with the addition of newer technologies like virtual reality. Just recently we worked with the Dulwich Picture Gallery—England’s oldest public art gallery—to take the young patients of King’s College Hospital in London on a virtual field trip to the museum using Google Cardboard.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-7cD5NFdC6VE/VqAtv5AG1TI/AAAAAAAARuQ/XqUIPcnhPBU/s1600/Malachi%252C%2Bage%2B12.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;426&quot; src=&quot;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-7cD5NFdC6VE/VqAtv5AG1TI/AAAAAAAARuQ/XqUIPcnhPBU/s640/Malachi%252C%2Bage%2B12.jpg&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;i&gt;Young patients at King’s College Hospital, London, were the first to experience the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/collection/dulwich-picture-gallery&quot;&gt;Dulwich Picture Gallery&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;in virtual reality&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Virtual visits will never replace the real thing. But technology can help open up art and culture to everyone, and we think that’s a powerful thing. As you browse the Google Cultural Institute’s 6 million objects exploring humanity’s diverse heritage across 70 countries—from this &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/asset-viewer/hand-axe/ggGRIHF4KE5MPw?projectId=art-project&quot;&gt;prehistoric equivalent of the Swiss Army knife&lt;/a&gt; in the Netherlands, to the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/entity/%2Fm%2F0l8cb&quot;&gt;Taj Mahal in India&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/exhibit/tezuka-osamu-manga-museum/ARLlaUsh&quot;&gt;manga drawings in Japan&lt;/a&gt;—we hope you’ll agree. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;byline-author&quot;&gt;Posted by Amit Sood, director of the Google Cultural Institute &lt;/span&gt;  &lt;span data-about-syndication=&quot;&quot; style=&quot;display: none; font-size: 0; line-height: 0; max-height: 0; overflow: hidden;&quot;&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-image&quot;&gt;IMAGE URL&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-name&quot;&gt;Amit Sood&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-title&quot;&gt;Director&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-team&quot;&gt;Google Cultural Institute &lt;/span&gt; &lt;/span&gt;</content><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/4249790036247043749'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/4249790036247043749'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2016/01/from-self-portraits-to-street-art-1000.html' title='From self-portraits to street art: 1,000 museums at your fingertips '/><author><name>Google Blogs</name><uri>https://plus.google.com/112374322230920073195</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//lh3.googleusercontent.com/-SMZmHeOVbFs/AAAAAAAAAAI/AAAAAAAAR7c/esUAZEvmr9M/s512-c/photo.jpg'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-qWgCrvkmIqA/VqAtv8miipI/AAAAAAAARuU/uRiMu2oM37w/s72-c/NL-%2BStreet%2BArt%2BMuseum%2BAmsterdam%252C%2B%25E2%2580%2598Gogh%2Bvan%2BCruijf%25E2%2580%2599%2Bby%2BUriginal%252C%2Bcompared%2Bto%2Bthe%2Boriginal%2BVan%2BGogh.png" height="72" width="72"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentSource" value="1"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentModerationMode" value="FILTERED_POSTMOD"/></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-10861780.post-4147720455393304174</id><published>2016-01-11T08:15:00.000-08:00</published><updated>2016-01-21T11:57:52.473-08:00</updated><title type='text'>YouTube creators interview President Obama following his final State of the Union </title><content type='html'>&lt;i&gt;&quot;We&#39;re going to have 21st century fireside chats where I&#39;ll speak directly to the American people in a way that I think will enhance democracy and strengthen our government.&quot;&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;- &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B1MGi12RspA&amp;amp;feature=youtu.be&amp;amp;t=2m3s&quot;&gt;Senator Barack Obama&lt;/a&gt;, November 15, 2007&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Tomorrow evening, President Obama will deliver his final State of the Union address to Congress, which will broadcast &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/user/whitehouse&quot;&gt;live on YouTube&lt;/a&gt;. Then, as he has every year after the speech, he’ll turn to YouTube and Google to take questions from Americans about the issues that matter to them.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;This Friday, January 15, &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1OQ5a_BtEso&quot;&gt;Destin Sandlin&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wKpch_KYVNM&quot;&gt;Ingrid Nilsen&lt;/a&gt;, and &lt;a href=&quot;https://youtu.be/tsfnYrAOPe0&quot;&gt;Adande Thorne&lt;/a&gt;—three popular YouTube creators—will travel to Washington, D.C. to host a live YouTube Interview with President Obama. They’ll join the President in the East Room of the White House, asking a selection of questions that are top of mind for them and their fans. You can watch the whole thing on the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/user/whitehouse&quot;&gt;White House YouTube channel&lt;/a&gt;—and if you have a question for the President, suggest it by using the hashtag #YouTubeAsksObama on social media.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;iframe allowfullscreen=&quot;&quot; frameborder=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;360&quot; src=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/embed/nySZH0tcL9I&quot; width=&quot;640&quot;&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The interview will stream live on the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/user/whitehouse&quot;&gt;White House YouTube channel&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;on Friday, January 15 at 2:15 p.m. EST. And don’t forget to tune in on January 12 at 9 p.m. EST to watch the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/user/whitehouse&quot;&gt;State of the Union address live&lt;/a&gt;, as well as the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.youtube.com/speakerryan&quot;&gt;Republican response&lt;/a&gt;, live on YouTube.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Throughout his time in office, President Obama has used technology to open up the doors (&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.whitehouse.gov/about/inside-white-house&quot;&gt;all 412 of them&lt;/a&gt;) to the White House—from posting behind-the-scenes &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/WhiteHouse/status/367301180910624768&quot;&gt;photos&lt;/a&gt; of life in the West Wing to uploading a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=proxBhvbNDA&quot;&gt;weekly address&lt;/a&gt; on the most pressing topics facing the nation. We’re excited to have played a role in this process with our seven YouTube Interviews, tackling issues &lt;a href=&quot;https://youtu.be/eeTj5qMGTAI?t=3m5s&quot;&gt;big&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://youtu.be/kp_zigxMS-Y?t=12m29s&quot;&gt;small&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://youtu.be/GbR6iQ62v9k?t=31m50s&quot;&gt;poignant&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://youtu.be/eeTj5qMGTAI?t=49m49s&quot;&gt;personal&lt;/a&gt;. We look forward to helping future presidents connect with Americans in compelling ways.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;byline-author&quot;&gt;Posted by Ramya Raghavan, Google Politics&lt;/span&gt;  &lt;span data-about-syndication=&quot;&quot; style=&quot;display: none; font-size: 0; line-height: 0; max-height: 0; mso-hide: all; overflow: hidden;&quot;&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-image&quot;&gt;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-MhmPKKW9HG8/VqE4EO5N31I/AAAAAAAARwI/yQrj7TLJqkg/s1600/YT%2BPOTUS%2B2.jpg&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-name&quot;&gt;Ramya Raghavan&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-team&quot;&gt;Google Politics&lt;/span&gt; &lt;/span&gt;</content><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/4147720455393304174'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/4147720455393304174'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2016/01/youtube-creators-interview-president.html' title='YouTube creators interview President Obama following his final State of the Union '/><author><name>Google Blogs</name><uri>https://plus.google.com/112374322230920073195</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//lh3.googleusercontent.com/-SMZmHeOVbFs/AAAAAAAAAAI/AAAAAAAAR7c/esUAZEvmr9M/s512-c/photo.jpg'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://img.youtube.com/vi/nySZH0tcL9I/default.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentSource" value="1"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentModerationMode" value="FILTERED_POSTMOD"/></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-10861780.post-8835131129048245034</id><published>2015-12-24T02:00:00.000-08:00</published><updated>2016-01-07T16:45:06.647-08:00</updated><title type='text'>‘Tis the season for Santa Tracker</title><content type='html'>‘Tis the night before Christmas, at our northernmost pole&lt;br /&gt;And all through Santa’s &lt;a href=&quot;https://santatracker.google.com/&quot;&gt;Village&lt;/a&gt; it’s almost time to roll.&lt;br /&gt;The elves have been working hard for this night&lt;br /&gt;Santa’s village is abuzz—&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YNpwm08ZRD0&amp;amp;feature=youtu.be&quot;&gt;tonight’s the big flight&lt;/a&gt;!&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Google’s &lt;a href=&quot;http://google.com/santatracker&quot;&gt;Santa Tracker&lt;/a&gt; launches today—&lt;br /&gt;And it’s time to follow the jolly man&#39;s sleigh. &lt;br /&gt;He’s off on his trip ‘round the world&lt;br /&gt;Delivering toys to all good boys and girls.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-RvXxSM5Otso/VnuVijvGnnI/AAAAAAAARoE/nVG_Xk9tkKA/s1600/SantaTracker2015_Tracker-on-all-devices.png&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;You’ve got a front-row seat to the show&lt;br /&gt;Just fire up Google Maps to see where he goes.&lt;br /&gt;Thanks to the elves’ precisely &lt;a href=&quot;https://santatracker.google.com/#codeboogie&quot;&gt;coded route&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Santa and his reindeer will fly swiftly—look out!&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-P-ZXfWXokYY/VnuViRl19cI/AAAAAAAARoA/Gf-dto9p3GU/s1600/SantaTracker2015_Code-Boogie_on-devices%2B%25282%2529.png&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;480&quot; src=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-P-ZXfWXokYY/VnuViRl19cI/AAAAAAAARoA/Gf-dto9p3GU/s640/SantaTracker2015_Code-Boogie_on-devices%2B%25282%2529.png&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Now the sleigh tuning’s done, &lt;br /&gt;Tales of global &lt;a href=&quot;https://santatracker.google.com/?hl=en#traditions&quot;&gt;traditions&lt;/a&gt; spun, &lt;br /&gt;Every gift in the sleigh &lt;a href=&quot;https://santatracker.google.com/?hl=en#presentdrop&quot;&gt;gently placed&lt;/a&gt;,&lt;br /&gt;Wrapped with care, without haste. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The reindeer are prancing and eager to fly,&lt;br /&gt;Ready for Santa’s trip through the sky.&lt;br /&gt;With so little time to get their job done—&lt;br /&gt;They may need your help on this gift-giving run. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;So keep the &lt;a href=&quot;https://santatracker.google.com/?hl=en#translations&quot;&gt;translation tool&lt;/a&gt; handy; &lt;br /&gt;Geography trivia would also be dandy.&lt;br /&gt;There’s no telling what Santa might need&lt;br /&gt;Traveling from Brisbane to Lima to Leeds.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-1YwXB3WTdds/VnuVirwrsBI/AAAAAAAARoI/rksH5jb1n_4/s1600/SantaTracker2015_World-Trivia_on-devices.png&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;480&quot; src=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-1YwXB3WTdds/VnuVirwrsBI/AAAAAAAARoI/rksH5jb1n_4/s640/SantaTracker2015_World-Trivia_on-devices.png&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Now Dasher! Now, Dancer! Now, Prancer and Vixen!&lt;br /&gt;Join in on the fun—find out what you’re missin’!&lt;br /&gt;On &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/maps/place/Santa/@84.6,168,14z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m2!3m1!1s0x0000000000001224:0x0000000000001225&quot;&gt;Maps&lt;/a&gt;! On &lt;a href=&quot;http://g.co/SantaApp&quot;&gt;Android&lt;/a&gt;, Chromecast and Google.com! &lt;br /&gt;There’s something for everyone, from kids to mom.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;So watch that sleigh as it takes to the air,&lt;br /&gt;And wherever you are, St. Nick will soon be there. &lt;br /&gt;To borrow a phrase, as Santa takes flight—&lt;br /&gt;&quot;Happy holidays to all, and to all a good-night!&quot;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;byline-author&quot;&gt;Posted by Luke Mahe, Chief Excitement Officer&lt;/span&gt;  &lt;span data-about-syndication=&quot;&quot; style=&quot;display: none; font-size: 0; line-height: 0; max-height: 0; mso-hide: all; overflow: hidden;&quot;&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-image&quot;&gt;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-F-nCS-J-76A/Vo8GNVQysoI/AAAAAAAARro/tl49aHijxhY/s1600/SantaTracker2015_2.jpg&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-name&quot;&gt;Luke Mahe&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-title&quot;&gt;Chief Excitement Officer&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;</content><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/8835131129048245034'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/8835131129048245034'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2015/12/tis-season-for-santa-tracker.html' title='‘Tis the season for Santa Tracker'/><author><name>Google Blogs</name><uri>https://plus.google.com/112374322230920073195</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//lh3.googleusercontent.com/-SMZmHeOVbFs/AAAAAAAAAAI/AAAAAAAAR7c/esUAZEvmr9M/s512-c/photo.jpg'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-RvXxSM5Otso/VnuVijvGnnI/AAAAAAAARoE/nVG_Xk9tkKA/s72-c/SantaTracker2015_Tracker-on-all-devices.png" height="72" width="72"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentSource" value="1"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentModerationMode" value="FILTERED_POSTMOD"/></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-10861780.post-5159679588467671417</id><published>2015-12-23T06:00:00.000-08:00</published><updated>2016-01-07T16:46:00.931-08:00</updated><title type='text'>We read the news today, oh boy: It’s The Beatles, on Google Play Music</title><content type='html'>No need for fussing or fighting, my friend. Now you can live on a Yellow Submarine, march in Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Band or go to Strawberry Fields Forever. Starting on December 24, all 13 of The Beatles’ iconic original albums, plus four essential Beatles collections, will be available to stream on Google Play Music—enough music to fill up eight days a week.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;iframe allowfullscreen=&quot;&quot; frameborder=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;360&quot; src=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/embed/8BHdO-aJQMk&quot; width=&quot;640&quot;&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The best-selling band in history, with 20 number one Billboard Hot 100 hits, The Beatles continue to be one of the world’s most beloved bands decades after their last original album. So, what lyrics take a sad song and make it better? What albums get you through a hard day’s night? Come together, right now, to take a look at some of the top Beatles searches, according to Google Trends.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-TmHDMzf4_60/VnpLxLBLUZI/AAAAAAAARng/hYIOf3n6aMg/s1600/Beatles2.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img alt=&quot;1. Abbey Road 2. Sgt. Pepper&#39;s Lonely Hearts Club Band 3. Help! 4. Let It Be 5. Magical Mystery Tour&quot; border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;319&quot; src=&quot;http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-TmHDMzf4_60/VnpLxLBLUZI/AAAAAAAARng/hYIOf3n6aMg/s640/Beatles2.jpg&quot; title=&quot;Most searched Beatles album&quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;separator&quot; style=&quot;clear: both; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-HFAkPV8iFBk/VnpLy25pvFI/AAAAAAAARns/YXh3FerXDl0/s1600/Beatles1.jpg&quot; imageanchor=&quot;1&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;&quot;&gt;&lt;img alt=&quot;1. Hey Jude 2. Yesterday 3. Come Together 4. Help! 5. Let It Be&quot; border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;319&quot; src=&quot;http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-HFAkPV8iFBk/VnpLy25pvFI/AAAAAAAARns/YXh3FerXDl0/s640/Beatles1.jpg&quot; title=&quot;Most searched Beatles song lyrics &quot; width=&quot;640&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Bonus: If you open up the Google app on your Android phone and say “Ok Google, play the Beatles,” There will be an answer. Let it stream.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;In the words of Ed Sullivan: “Ladies and Gentlemen, The Beatles!”&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;byline-author&quot;&gt;Posted by Gwen Shen, Music Partnerships, Google Play&lt;/span&gt;  &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span data-about-syndication=&quot;&quot; style=&quot;display: none; font-size: 0; line-height: 0; max-height: 0; mso-hide: all; overflow: hidden;&quot;&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-image&quot;&gt;http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-lAaDf35rKZo/Vo8GMQnf3-I/AAAAAAAARrk/KDMg871KKHc/s1600/Beatles_2.png&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-name&quot;&gt;Gwen Shen&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-title&quot;&gt;Music Partnerships&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;post-author-team&quot;&gt;Google Play&lt;/span&gt; &lt;/span&gt;</content><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/5159679588467671417'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/10861780/posts/default/5159679588467671417'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2015/12/we-read-news-today-oh-boy-its-beatles.html' title='We read the news today, oh boy: It’s The Beatles, on Google Play Music'/><author><name>Google Blogs</name><uri>https://plus.google.com/112374322230920073195</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='32' src='//lh3.googleusercontent.com/-SMZmHeOVbFs/AAAAAAAAAAI/AAAAAAAAR7c/esUAZEvmr9M/s512-c/photo.jpg'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" url="http://img.youtube.com/vi/8BHdO-aJQMk/default.jpg" height="72" width="72"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentSource" value="1"/><gd:extendedProperty name="commentModerationMode" value="FILTERED_POSTMOD"/></entry></feed>

		<title>Samsung wants you to stop checking your phone while on your motorbike</title>
		<link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/TheNextWeb/~3/rEtYeuhI5lk/</link>
		<comments>http://thenextweb.com/gadgets/2016/03/22/samsung-smart-windshield/#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Tue, 22 Mar 2016 11:17:34 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Amanda Connolly]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Gadgets]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://thenextweb.com/?p=964230</guid>
		<description>&lt;img width="520" height="245" src="http://cdn1.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2016/03/Screen-Shot-2016-03-22-at-10.49.25-520x245.png" alt="Screen Shot 2016-03-22 at 10.49.25" title="Samsung wants you to stop checking your phone while on your motorbike" data-id="964260" /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;While almost everyone is focusing on keeping drivers’ hands off the wheel in autonomous cars, Samsung has turned its attention to keeping drivers’ hands firmly on the handlebars when it comes to motorcycles. Partnering with advertising company Leo Burnett, motocross star Edo Mossi and YouTuber Cane Secco to develop a prototype for its Smart Windshield, Samsung’s main aim is to keep drivers attention on the road. The company has deliberately picked Italian stars to partner on the campaign, as it says that 25 percent of motorcycle crashes in the country among young people are down to phone use. The idea behind the&amp;#8230; &lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="http://thenextweb.com/gadgets/2016/03/22/samsung-smart-windshield/?utm_source=social&amp;#038;utm_medium=feed&amp;#038;utm_campaign=profeed"&gt;This story continues&lt;/a&gt; at The Next Web&lt;div class="feedflare"&gt;
&lt;a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?a=rEtYeuhI5lk:u8zZvg4Mmfs:D7DqB2pKExk"&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?i=rEtYeuhI5lk:u8zZvg4Mmfs:D7DqB2pKExk" border="0"&gt;&lt;/img&gt;&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?a=rEtYeuhI5lk:u8zZvg4Mmfs:yIl2AUoC8zA"&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"&gt;&lt;/img&gt;&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?a=rEtYeuhI5lk:u8zZvg4Mmfs:V_sGLiPBpWU"&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?i=rEtYeuhI5lk:u8zZvg4Mmfs:V_sGLiPBpWU" border="0"&gt;&lt;/img&gt;&lt;/a&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/TheNextWeb/~4/rEtYeuhI5lk" height="1" width="1" alt=""/&gt;</description>

		<title>90% of people would opt for a faster phone over a secure one</title>
		<link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/TheNextWeb/~3/hQIXefE4ctc/</link>
		<comments>http://thenextweb.com/shareables/2016/03/22/90-of-people-would-opt-for-a-faster-phone-over-a-secure-one/#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Tue, 22 Mar 2016 10:38:30 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Kirsty Styles]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Insider]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[Shareables]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://thenextweb.com/?p=964228</guid>
		<description>&lt;img width="520" height="245" src="http://cdn1.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2012/11/security_fence-520x245.jpg" alt="security_fence" title="90% of people would opt for a faster phone over a secure one" data-id="497021" /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The FBI and Apple encryption debate has certainly brought both regulators and the tech community to life in the US, but it turns out we’d rather have a high-performing or cheap smartphone than one that looks after our personal data. A Reuters and Ipsos poll conducted this month found that just one in 10 Americans say security is the most important feature for them when buying a phone, while performance or price both top the list for a third of people each. Around 60 percent of the 1,703 people surveyed said they trust Apple to protect their data, which was no more than other&amp;#8230; &lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="http://thenextweb.com/shareables/2016/03/22/90-of-people-would-opt-for-a-faster-phone-over-a-secure-one/?utm_source=social&amp;#038;utm_medium=feed&amp;#038;utm_campaign=profeed"&gt;This story continues&lt;/a&gt; at The Next Web&lt;div class="feedflare"&gt;
&lt;a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?a=hQIXefE4ctc:4TjiOZI_-fo:D7DqB2pKExk"&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?i=hQIXefE4ctc:4TjiOZI_-fo:D7DqB2pKExk" border="0"&gt;&lt;/img&gt;&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?a=hQIXefE4ctc:4TjiOZI_-fo:yIl2AUoC8zA"&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"&gt;&lt;/img&gt;&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?a=hQIXefE4ctc:4TjiOZI_-fo:V_sGLiPBpWU"&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?i=hQIXefE4ctc:4TjiOZI_-fo:V_sGLiPBpWU" border="0"&gt;&lt;/img&gt;&lt;/a&gt;

		<title>The BBC’s Raspberry Pi-like computer has rolled out to 1m students and you can soon buy one</title>
		<link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/TheNextWeb/~3/6VMOBSRBpFg/</link>
		<comments>http://thenextweb.com/gadgets/2016/03/22/bbcs-raspberry-pi-like-computer-rolled-1m-students-can-soon-buy-one/#respond</comments>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://thenextweb.com/?p=964229</guid>
		<description>&lt;img width="520" height="245" src="http://cdn1.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2016/03/BBC-Micro-Bit-520x245.jpg" alt="BBC Micro Bit" title="The BBC&amp;#039;s Raspberry Pi-like computer has rolled out to 1m students and you can soon buy one" data-id="964233" /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;After months of delay, the BBC has launched its Micro Bit programmable computer, beginning with about a million of them being delivered for free to every child in year 7 (around 12 years old) across England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland. Once they receive their own Micro Bits during this rollout, kids will be able to keep and use them throughout their remaining years at school. It’s part of the BBC’s program to encourage children to learn to code and creative with technology. The device will be available to buy from a range of retailers soon after today’s rollout; a&amp;#8230; &lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="http://thenextweb.com/gadgets/2016/03/22/bbcs-raspberry-pi-like-computer-rolled-1m-students-can-soon-buy-one/?utm_source=social&amp;#038;utm_medium=feed&amp;#038;utm_campaign=profeed"&gt;This story continues&lt;/a&gt; at The Next Web&lt;div class="feedflare"&gt;

		<link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/TheNextWeb/~3/X-Zp4e-ak-Q/</link>
		<comments>http://thenextweb.com/insider/2016/03/22/indie-developer-sells-300000-copies-game-finds-1-million-pirated-copies/#respond</comments>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://thenextweb.com/?p=964231</guid>
		<description>&lt;img width="520" height="245" src="http://thenextweb.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2016/03/pirated-a-looooot-520x245.png" alt="pirated-a-looooot" title="Indie developer sold 300,000 copies of its game but found more than 1 million pirated copies" data-id="964240" /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Punch Club, a game built by indie developers Tiny Build, was released in January but the company was surprised to see how many users pirated the game just two months in. In a post released today the company detailed that while its game had been sold 300,000 times, it found that the game had been pirated more than 1.6 million times with the sheer majority coming from PC gamers. The company used Unity Analytics as well as third-party tracking tools to discover when the game was legally used versus when it wasn’t and accounted for those that might have used it on&amp;#8230; &lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="http://thenextweb.com/insider/2016/03/22/indie-developer-sells-300000-copies-game-finds-1-million-pirated-copies/?utm_source=social&amp;#038;utm_medium=feed&amp;#038;utm_campaign=profeed"&gt;This story continues&lt;/a&gt; at The Next Web&lt;div class="feedflare"&gt;

		<title>It’s time for BlackBerry to pull the plug on its mobile OS</title>
		<link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/TheNextWeb/~3/c0AJ97ymWgs/</link>
		<comments>http://thenextweb.com/mobile/2016/03/22/time-blackberry-pull-plug-mobile-os/#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Tue, 22 Mar 2016 08:36:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Abhimanyu Ghoshal]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Mobile]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Facebook]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[whatsapp]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://thenextweb.com/?p=964217</guid>
		<description>&lt;img width="520" height="245" src="http://cdn1.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2016/03/BlackBerry-Passport-520x245.jpg" alt="BlackBerry Passport" title="It&amp;#039;s time for BlackBerry to pull the plug on its mobile OS" data-id="964218" /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Last week, Facebook decided to drop support for BlackBerry’s mobile OS, which means its app will soon cease to work on the company’s devices. Once the app disappears from BlackBerry World, users will have to visit the social network’s site to access it. It’s the latest in a series of developments pointing to the slow but eventual demise of BlackBerry’s platform. Last month, WhatsApp announced its plans to discontinue its BlackBerry 10 and BBOS apps by the end of the year. That’s two of the world’s most popular apps crossed off the company’s roster this year. BlackBerry took its time&amp;#8230; &lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="http://thenextweb.com/mobile/2016/03/22/time-blackberry-pull-plug-mobile-os/?utm_source=social&amp;#038;utm_medium=feed&amp;#038;utm_campaign=profeed"&gt;This story continues&lt;/a&gt; at The Next Web&lt;div class="feedflare"&gt;

		<title>The iPhone SE costs $200 more in India and I’d still buy it</title>
		<link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/TheNextWeb/~3/UGAyRMbGb0c/</link>
		<comments>http://thenextweb.com/apple/2016/03/22/iphone-se-costs-200-india-id-still-buy/#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Tue, 22 Mar 2016 06:05:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Abhimanyu Ghoshal]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Apple]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[India]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[Mobile]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[iPhone SE]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[pricing]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://thenextweb.com/?p=964210</guid>
		<description>&lt;img width="520" height="245" src="http://cdn1.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2016/03/iPhone-SE-520x245.jpg" alt="iPhone SE" title="The iPhone SE costs $200 more in India and I&amp;#039;d still buy it" data-id="964211" /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Shortly after Apple announced the all-new 4-inch iPhone SE with a reasonable $399 (Rs. 26,600) price tag, fans in India were annoyed to learn that the device would become available locally next month for nearly $200 more at $586 (Rs. 39,000). I’m perhaps as far from an Apple fanboy as a tech enthusiast can be — I exclusively use Windows computers and rely on Android for my primary phone. But even at this price, I’m still keen to get my hands on an iPhone SE. For one thing, it brings back my favorite iPhone design, the one from the 5s. I&amp;#8230; &lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="http://thenextweb.com/apple/2016/03/22/iphone-se-costs-200-india-id-still-buy/?utm_source=social&amp;#038;utm_medium=feed&amp;#038;utm_campaign=profeed"&gt;This story continues&lt;/a&gt; at The Next Web&lt;div class="feedflare"&gt;

		<item>
		<title>Former Intel CEO Andy Grove has died at 79</title>
		<link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/TheNextWeb/~3/_BvkaMtMEMY/</link>
		<comments>http://thenextweb.com/insider/2016/03/22/former-intel-ceo-andy-grove-died-79/#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Tue, 22 Mar 2016 04:27:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Abhimanyu Ghoshal]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Insider]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[Andy Grove]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[intel]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[Obituary]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://thenextweb.com/?p=964204</guid>
		<description>&lt;img width="520" height="245" src="http://cdn1.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2016/03/Andy-Grove-520x245.jpg" alt="Andy Grove" title="Former Intel CEO Andy Grove has died at 79" data-id="964205" /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Andrew Grove, Intel’s former CEO and Chairman passed away today at the age of 79. He was the company’s first hire when it was founded in 1968 and went on to become its CEO in 1987. Under Grove’s leadership, Intel transitioned from manufacturing memory chips to microprocessors like the 386 and Pentium. He also was responsible for growing the company’s annual revenues more than tenfold, from $1.9 billion to over $26 billion. Intel Chairman Andy Bryant said in a statement: Andy approached corporate strategy and leadership in ways that continue to influence prominent thinkers and companies around the world. He&amp;#8230; &lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="http://thenextweb.com/insider/2016/03/22/former-intel-ceo-andy-grove-died-79/?utm_source=social&amp;#038;utm_medium=feed&amp;#038;utm_campaign=profeed"&gt;This story continues&lt;/a&gt; at The Next Web&lt;div class="feedflare"&gt;
&lt;a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?a=_BvkaMtMEMY:_uNNzXYxJOk:D7DqB2pKExk"&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?i=_BvkaMtMEMY:_uNNzXYxJOk:D7DqB2pKExk" border="0"&gt;&lt;/img&gt;&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?a=_BvkaMtMEMY:_uNNzXYxJOk:yIl2AUoC8zA"&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"&gt;&lt;/img&gt;&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?a=_BvkaMtMEMY:_uNNzXYxJOk:V_sGLiPBpWU"&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?i=_BvkaMtMEMY:_uNNzXYxJOk:V_sGLiPBpWU" border="0"&gt;&lt;/img&gt;&lt;/a&gt;

		<title>Adobe’s new co-op lets brands know which devices you use so you don’t see too many ads</title>
		<link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/TheNextWeb/~3/tug52l2U4o4/</link>
		<comments>http://thenextweb.com/insider/2016/03/22/adobe-creating-advertising-co-op-brands-will-stop-annoying/#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Tue, 22 Mar 2016 03:59:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Nate Swanner]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Insider]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://thenextweb.com/?p=964189</guid>
		<description>&lt;img width="520" height="245" src="http://cdn1.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2016/03/AdobecoopTNW-520x245.jpg" alt="AdobecoopTNW" title="Adobe&amp;#039;s new co-op lets brands know which devices you use so you don&amp;#039;t see too many ads" data-id="964190" /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Adobe has a smart new way of letting advertisers market to consumers, and it just might work out for everyone involved. With what they call the Device Co-op, Adobe is making the ads you see about you, not how many devices you own. When brands join the co-op, it allows those companies to see which devices you’re using so you don’t get multiple impressions. Adobe thinks the current methods for gauging how to reach users has failed because it’s not about people. Rather than using cookies and sessions — which advertisers count as impressions — Adobe is targeting people. Here’s&amp;#8230; &lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="http://thenextweb.com/insider/2016/03/22/adobe-creating-advertising-co-op-brands-will-stop-annoying/?utm_source=social&amp;#038;utm_medium=feed&amp;#038;utm_campaign=profeed"&gt;This story continues&lt;/a&gt; at The Next Web&lt;div class="feedflare"&gt;
&lt;a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?a=tug52l2U4o4:jykWviveniE:D7DqB2pKExk"&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?i=tug52l2U4o4:jykWviveniE:D7DqB2pKExk" border="0"&gt;&lt;/img&gt;&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?a=tug52l2U4o4:jykWviveniE:yIl2AUoC8zA"&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"&gt;&lt;/img&gt;&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?a=tug52l2U4o4:jykWviveniE:V_sGLiPBpWU"&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?i=tug52l2U4o4:jykWviveniE:V_sGLiPBpWU" border="0"&gt;&lt;/img&gt;&lt;/a&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/TheNextWeb/~4/tug52l2U4o4" height="1" width="1" alt=""/&gt;</description>

		<description>&lt;img width="520" height="245" src="http://cdn1.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2016/03/USBCLightningTNW-520x245.jpg" alt="USBCLightningTNW" title="Apple now has a USB-C to Lightning cable, and it could suggest a new MacBook Pro feature" data-id="964176" /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Apple events always bring great products, but some are quietly introduced in the background. That’s the case with a new USB-C to Lightning cable discovered on the Apple website. Available in both one and two meter lengths ($25 and $35, respectively), the cable lets you plug an iPhone, iPad or iPod right into your MacBook. You can use it for data transfer, or to power your mobile devices. It’s an interesting time to release a cable like this, though. Ahead of today’s event, there were rumblings we may see a Mac Mini refresh, or perhaps Apple would catch us by&amp;#8230; &lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="http://thenextweb.com/apple/2016/03/22/apple-usb-c-to-lightning-cable-released/?utm_source=social&amp;#038;utm_medium=feed&amp;#038;utm_campaign=profeed"&gt;This story continues&lt;/a&gt; at The Next Web&lt;div class="feedflare"&gt;

		<description>&lt;img width="520" height="245" src="http://cdn1.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2016/03/Screen-Shot-2016-03-22-at-10.49.25-520x245.png" alt="Screen Shot 2016-03-22 at 10.49.25" title="Samsung wants you to stop checking your phone while on your motorbike" data-id="964260" /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;While almost everyone is focusing on keeping drivers’ hands off the wheel in autonomous cars, Samsung has turned its attention to keeping drivers’ hands firmly on the handlebars when it comes to motorcycles. Partnering with advertising company Leo Burnett, motocross star Edo Mossi and YouTuber Cane Secco to develop a prototype for its Smart Windshield, Samsung’s main aim is to keep drivers attention on the road. The company has deliberately picked Italian stars to partner on the campaign, as it says that 25 percent of motorcycle crashes in the country among young people are down to phone use. The idea behind the&amp;#8230; &lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="http://thenextweb.com/gadgets/2016/03/22/samsung-smart-windshield/?utm_source=social&amp;#038;utm_medium=feed&amp;#038;utm_campaign=profeed"&gt;This story continues&lt;/a&gt; at The Next Web&lt;div class="feedflare"&gt;

		<description>&lt;img width="520" height="245" src="http://cdn1.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2012/11/security_fence-520x245.jpg" alt="security_fence" title="90% of people would opt for a faster phone over a secure one" data-id="497021" /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The FBI and Apple encryption debate has certainly brought both regulators and the tech community to life in the US, but it turns out we’d rather have a high-performing or cheap smartphone than one that looks after our personal data. A Reuters and Ipsos poll conducted this month found that just one in 10 Americans say security is the most important feature for them when buying a phone, while performance or price both top the list for a third of people each. Around 60 percent of the 1,703 people surveyed said they trust Apple to protect their data, which was no more than other&amp;#8230; &lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="http://thenextweb.com/shareables/2016/03/22/90-of-people-would-opt-for-a-faster-phone-over-a-secure-one/?utm_source=social&amp;#038;utm_medium=feed&amp;#038;utm_campaign=profeed"&gt;This story continues&lt;/a&gt; at The Next Web&lt;div class="feedflare"&gt;

		<description>&lt;img width="520" height="245" src="http://cdn1.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2016/03/BBC-Micro-Bit-520x245.jpg" alt="BBC Micro Bit" title="The BBC&amp;#039;s Raspberry Pi-like computer has rolled out to 1m students and you can soon buy one" data-id="964233" /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;After months of delay, the BBC has launched its Micro Bit programmable computer, beginning with about a million of them being delivered for free to every child in year 7 (around 12 years old) across England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland. Once they receive their own Micro Bits during this rollout, kids will be able to keep and use them throughout their remaining years at school. It’s part of the BBC’s program to encourage children to learn to code and creative with technology. The device will be available to buy from a range of retailers soon after today’s rollout; a&amp;#8230; &lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="http://thenextweb.com/gadgets/2016/03/22/bbcs-raspberry-pi-like-computer-rolled-1m-students-can-soon-buy-one/?utm_source=social&amp;#038;utm_medium=feed&amp;#038;utm_campaign=profeed"&gt;This story continues&lt;/a&gt; at The Next Web&lt;div class="feedflare"&gt;

		<title>Indie developer sold 300,000 copies of its game but found more than 1 million pirated copies</title>
		<link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/TheNextWeb/~3/X-Zp4e-ak-Q/</link>
		<comments>http://thenextweb.com/insider/2016/03/22/indie-developer-sells-300000-copies-game-finds-1-million-pirated-copies/#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Tue, 22 Mar 2016 10:28:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Owen Williams]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Insider]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://thenextweb.com/?p=964231</guid>
		<description>&lt;img width="520" height="245" src="http://thenextweb.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2016/03/pirated-a-looooot-520x245.png" alt="pirated-a-looooot" title="Indie developer sold 300,000 copies of its game but found more than 1 million pirated copies" data-id="964240" /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Punch Club, a game built by indie developers Tiny Build, was released in January but the company was surprised to see how many users pirated the game just two months in. In a post released today the company detailed that while its game had been sold 300,000 times, it found that the game had been pirated more than 1.6 million times with the sheer majority coming from PC gamers. The company used Unity Analytics as well as third-party tracking tools to discover when the game was legally used versus when it wasn’t and accounted for those that might have used it on&amp;#8230; &lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="http://thenextweb.com/insider/2016/03/22/indie-developer-sells-300000-copies-game-finds-1-million-pirated-copies/?utm_source=social&amp;#038;utm_medium=feed&amp;#038;utm_campaign=profeed"&gt;This story continues&lt;/a&gt; at The Next Web&lt;div class="feedflare"&gt;
&lt;a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?a=X-Zp4e-ak-Q:jRNdLDWwheo:D7DqB2pKExk"&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?i=X-Zp4e-ak-Q:jRNdLDWwheo:D7DqB2pKExk" border="0"&gt;&lt;/img&gt;&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?a=X-Zp4e-ak-Q:jRNdLDWwheo:yIl2AUoC8zA"&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"&gt;&lt;/img&gt;&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?a=X-Zp4e-ak-Q:jRNdLDWwheo:V_sGLiPBpWU"&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?i=X-Zp4e-ak-Q:jRNdLDWwheo:V_sGLiPBpWU" border="0"&gt;&lt;/img&gt;&lt;/a&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/TheNextWeb/~4/X-Zp4e-ak-Q" height="1" width="1" alt=""/&gt;</description>

		<title>It’s time for BlackBerry to pull the plug on its mobile OS</title>
		<link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/TheNextWeb/~3/c0AJ97ymWgs/</link>
		<comments>http://thenextweb.com/mobile/2016/03/22/time-blackberry-pull-plug-mobile-os/#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Tue, 22 Mar 2016 08:36:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Abhimanyu Ghoshal]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Facebook]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[whatsapp]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://thenextweb.com/?p=964217</guid>
		<description>&lt;img width="520" height="245" src="http://cdn1.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2016/03/BlackBerry-Passport-520x245.jpg" alt="BlackBerry Passport" title="It&amp;#039;s time for BlackBerry to pull the plug on its mobile OS" data-id="964218" /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Last week, Facebook decided to drop support for BlackBerry’s mobile OS, which means its app will soon cease to work on the company’s devices. Once the app disappears from BlackBerry World, users will have to visit the social network’s site to access it. It’s the latest in a series of developments pointing to the slow but eventual demise of BlackBerry’s platform. Last month, WhatsApp announced its plans to discontinue its BlackBerry 10 and BBOS apps by the end of the year. That’s two of the world’s most popular apps crossed off the company’s roster this year. BlackBerry took its time&amp;#8230; &lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="http://thenextweb.com/mobile/2016/03/22/time-blackberry-pull-plug-mobile-os/?utm_source=social&amp;#038;utm_medium=feed&amp;#038;utm_campaign=profeed"&gt;This story continues&lt;/a&gt; at The Next Web&lt;div class="feedflare"&gt;

		<title>The iPhone SE costs $200 more in India and I’d still buy it</title>
		<link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/TheNextWeb/~3/UGAyRMbGb0c/</link>

		<description>&lt;img width="520" height="245" src="http://cdn1.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2016/03/iPhone-SE-520x245.jpg" alt="iPhone SE" title="The iPhone SE costs $200 more in India and I&amp;#039;d still buy it" data-id="964211" /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Shortly after Apple announced the all-new 4-inch iPhone SE with a reasonable $399 (Rs. 26,600) price tag, fans in India were annoyed to learn that the device would become available locally next month for nearly $200 more at $586 (Rs. 39,000). I’m perhaps as far from an Apple fanboy as a tech enthusiast can be — I exclusively use Windows computers and rely on Android for my primary phone. But even at this price, I’m still keen to get my hands on an iPhone SE. For one thing, it brings back my favorite iPhone design, the one from the 5s. I&amp;#8230; &lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="http://thenextweb.com/apple/2016/03/22/iphone-se-costs-200-india-id-still-buy/?utm_source=social&amp;#038;utm_medium=feed&amp;#038;utm_campaign=profeed"&gt;This story continues&lt;/a&gt; at The Next Web&lt;div class="feedflare"&gt;

		<title>Former Intel CEO Andy Grove has died at 79</title>
		<link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/TheNextWeb/~3/_BvkaMtMEMY/</link>
		<comments>http://thenextweb.com/insider/2016/03/22/former-intel-ceo-andy-grove-died-79/#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Tue, 22 Mar 2016 04:27:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Abhimanyu Ghoshal]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Insider]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[Andy Grove]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[intel]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[Obituary]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://thenextweb.com/?p=964204</guid>
		<description>&lt;img width="520" height="245" src="http://cdn1.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2016/03/Andy-Grove-520x245.jpg" alt="Andy Grove" title="Former Intel CEO Andy Grove has died at 79" data-id="964205" /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Andrew Grove, Intel’s former CEO and Chairman passed away today at the age of 79. He was the company’s first hire when it was founded in 1968 and went on to become its CEO in 1987. Under Grove’s leadership, Intel transitioned from manufacturing memory chips to microprocessors like the 386 and Pentium. He also was responsible for growing the company’s annual revenues more than tenfold, from $1.9 billion to over $26 billion. Intel Chairman Andy Bryant said in a statement: Andy approached corporate strategy and leadership in ways that continue to influence prominent thinkers and companies around the world. He&amp;#8230; &lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="http://thenextweb.com/insider/2016/03/22/former-intel-ceo-andy-grove-died-79/?utm_source=social&amp;#038;utm_medium=feed&amp;#038;utm_campaign=profeed"&gt;This story continues&lt;/a&gt; at The Next Web&lt;div class="feedflare"&gt;
&lt;a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?a=_BvkaMtMEMY:_uNNzXYxJOk:D7DqB2pKExk"&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?i=_BvkaMtMEMY:_uNNzXYxJOk:D7DqB2pKExk" border="0"&gt;&lt;/img&gt;&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?a=_BvkaMtMEMY:_uNNzXYxJOk:yIl2AUoC8zA"&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"&gt;&lt;/img&gt;&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?a=_BvkaMtMEMY:_uNNzXYxJOk:V_sGLiPBpWU"&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?i=_BvkaMtMEMY:_uNNzXYxJOk:V_sGLiPBpWU" border="0"&gt;&lt;/img&gt;&lt;/a&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/TheNextWeb/~4/_BvkaMtMEMY" height="1" width="1" alt=""/&gt;</description>

		<item>
		<title>Adobe’s new co-op lets brands know which devices you use so you don’t see too many ads</title>
		<link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/TheNextWeb/~3/tug52l2U4o4/</link>
		<comments>http://thenextweb.com/insider/2016/03/22/adobe-creating-advertising-co-op-brands-will-stop-annoying/#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Tue, 22 Mar 2016 03:59:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Nate Swanner]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Insider]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://thenextweb.com/?p=964189</guid>
		<description>&lt;img width="520" height="245" src="http://cdn1.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2016/03/AdobecoopTNW-520x245.jpg" alt="AdobecoopTNW" title="Adobe&amp;#039;s new co-op lets brands know which devices you use so you don&amp;#039;t see too many ads" data-id="964190" /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Adobe has a smart new way of letting advertisers market to consumers, and it just might work out for everyone involved. With what they call the Device Co-op, Adobe is making the ads you see about you, not how many devices you own. When brands join the co-op, it allows those companies to see which devices you’re using so you don’t get multiple impressions. Adobe thinks the current methods for gauging how to reach users has failed because it’s not about people. Rather than using cookies and sessions — which advertisers count as impressions — Adobe is targeting people. Here’s&amp;#8230; &lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="http://thenextweb.com/insider/2016/03/22/adobe-creating-advertising-co-op-brands-will-stop-annoying/?utm_source=social&amp;#038;utm_medium=feed&amp;#038;utm_campaign=profeed"&gt;This story continues&lt;/a&gt; at The Next Web&lt;div class="feedflare"&gt;
&lt;a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?a=tug52l2U4o4:jykWviveniE:D7DqB2pKExk"&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?i=tug52l2U4o4:jykWviveniE:D7DqB2pKExk" border="0"&gt;&lt;/img&gt;&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?a=tug52l2U4o4:jykWviveniE:yIl2AUoC8zA"&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"&gt;&lt;/img&gt;&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?a=tug52l2U4o4:jykWviveniE:V_sGLiPBpWU"&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?i=tug52l2U4o4:jykWviveniE:V_sGLiPBpWU" border="0"&gt;&lt;/img&gt;&lt;/a&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/TheNextWeb/~4/tug52l2U4o4" height="1" width="1" alt=""/&gt;</description>
		<wfw:commentRss>http://thenextweb.com/insider/2016/03/22/adobe-creating-advertising-co-op-brands-will-stop-annoying/feed/</wfw:commentRss>

		<title>Apple now has a USB-C to Lightning cable, and it could suggest a new MacBook Pro feature</title>
		<link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/TheNextWeb/~3/vH8PcL0ls1k/</link>
		<comments>http://thenextweb.com/apple/2016/03/22/apple-usb-c-to-lightning-cable-released/#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Tue, 22 Mar 2016 00:20:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Nate Swanner]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Apple]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[apple 2016]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://thenextweb.com/?p=964175</guid>
		<description>&lt;img width="520" height="245" src="http://cdn1.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2016/03/USBCLightningTNW-520x245.jpg" alt="USBCLightningTNW" title="Apple now has a USB-C to Lightning cable, and it could suggest a new MacBook Pro feature" data-id="964176" /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Apple events always bring great products, but some are quietly introduced in the background. That’s the case with a new USB-C to Lightning cable discovered on the Apple website. Available in both one and two meter lengths ($25 and $35, respectively), the cable lets you plug an iPhone, iPad or iPod right into your MacBook. You can use it for data transfer, or to power your mobile devices. It’s an interesting time to release a cable like this, though. Ahead of today’s event, there were rumblings we may see a Mac Mini refresh, or perhaps Apple would catch us by&amp;#8230; &lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="http://thenextweb.com/apple/2016/03/22/apple-usb-c-to-lightning-cable-released/?utm_source=social&amp;#038;utm_medium=feed&amp;#038;utm_campaign=profeed"&gt;This story continues&lt;/a&gt; at The Next Web&lt;div class="feedflare"&gt;
&lt;a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?a=vH8PcL0ls1k:Y0BBMbnYXII:D7DqB2pKExk"&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?i=vH8PcL0ls1k:Y0BBMbnYXII:D7DqB2pKExk" border="0"&gt;&lt;/img&gt;&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?a=vH8PcL0ls1k:Y0BBMbnYXII:yIl2AUoC8zA"&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"&gt;&lt;/img&gt;&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?a=vH8PcL0ls1k:Y0BBMbnYXII:V_sGLiPBpWU"&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/TheNextWeb?i=vH8PcL0ls1k:Y0BBMbnYXII:V_sGLiPBpWU" border="0"&gt;&lt;/img&gt;&lt;/a&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/TheNextWeb/~4/vH8PcL0ls1k" height="1" width="1" alt=""/&gt;</description>

	<item>
		<title>Harvard Blue Book: peace in our time?</title>
		<link>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/22/harvard-blue-book-peace-in-ou.html</link>
		<comments>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/22/harvard-blue-book-peace-in-ou.html#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Tue, 22 Mar 2016 10:52:46 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Cory Doctorow]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Post]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[Copyfight]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[law]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[scholarship]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[the rule of rules of law]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://boingboing.net/?p=453521</guid>
		
		

		<description><![CDATA[<p><img width="1280" height="960" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Bluebook-Legal-Bluebook.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="Bluebook-Legal-Bluebook" srcset="http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Bluebook-Legal-Bluebook.jpg?resize=300%2C225 300w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Bluebook-Legal-Bluebook.jpg?resize=600%2C450 600w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Bluebook-Legal-Bluebook.jpg?resize=768%2C576 768w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Bluebook-Legal-Bluebook.jpg?resize=930%2C698 930w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Bluebook-Legal-Bluebook.jpg?w=1280 1280w" sizes="(max-width: 1280px) 100vw, 1280px" /></p>
<p>
Rogue archivist Carl Malamud writes, "Readers may recall a long-simmering dispute over the use of common abbreviations
required in citations, a technical standard known as the Uniform System of Citation.
One explanation of that standard is a manual every law student knows, The Bluebook,
long published by the Harvard Law Review Association in cooperation with 3 other law
schools."

 <a href="http://boingboing.net/2016/03/22/harvard-blue-book-peace-in-ou.html#more-453521" class="more-link">(more&hellip;)</a></p>]]></description>
    <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><img width="1280" height="960" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Bluebook-Legal-Bluebook.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="Bluebook-Legal-Bluebook" srcset="http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Bluebook-Legal-Bluebook.jpg?resize=300%2C225 300w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Bluebook-Legal-Bluebook.jpg?resize=600%2C450 600w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Bluebook-Legal-Bluebook.jpg?resize=768%2C576 768w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Bluebook-Legal-Bluebook.jpg?resize=930%2C698 930w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Bluebook-Legal-Bluebook.jpg?w=1280 1280w" sizes="(max-width: 1280px) 100vw, 1280px" /></p>
<p>
Rogue archivist Carl Malamud writes, "Readers may recall a long-simmering dispute over the use of common abbreviations
required in citations, a technical standard known as the Uniform System of Citation.
One explanation of that standard is a manual every law student knows, The Bluebook,
long published by the Harvard Law Review Association in cooperation with 3 other law
schools."

 <a href="http://boingboing.net/2016/03/22/harvard-blue-book-peace-in-ou.html#more-453521" class="more-link">(more&hellip;)</a></p>]]></content:encoded>

		<link>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/22/silverpush-says-its-not-in-t.html</link>

		<pubDate>Tue, 22 Mar 2016 07:26:55 +0000</pubDate>

		<description><![CDATA[<p><img width="1000" height="600" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/silverpush.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="silverpush" srcset="http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/silverpush.jpg?resize=300%2C180 300w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/silverpush.jpg?resize=600%2C360 600w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/silverpush.jpg?resize=768%2C461 768w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/silverpush.jpg?resize=930%2C558 930w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/silverpush.jpg?w=1000 1000w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /></p>
<p>
Silverpush, the company that pioneered <a href="http://boingboing.net/2015/11/13/startup-uses-ultrasound-chirps.html">covert ultrasonic audio beacons</a> that let advertisers link your activity on phones, tablets and laptops, says it will no longer sell the technology and does not want to be associated with the idea any longer.
 <a href="http://boingboing.net/2016/03/22/silverpush-says-its-not-in-t.html#more-453513" class="more-link">(more&hellip;)</a></p>]]></description>
    <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><img width="1000" height="600" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/silverpush.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="silverpush" srcset="http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/silverpush.jpg?resize=300%2C180 300w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/silverpush.jpg?resize=600%2C360 600w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/silverpush.jpg?resize=768%2C461 768w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/silverpush.jpg?resize=930%2C558 930w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/silverpush.jpg?w=1000 1000w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /></p>
<p>
Silverpush, the company that pioneered <a href="http://boingboing.net/2015/11/13/startup-uses-ultrasound-chirps.html">covert ultrasonic audio beacons</a> that let advertisers link your activity on phones, tablets and laptops, says it will no longer sell the technology and does not want to be associated with the idea any longer.
 <a href="http://boingboing.net/2016/03/22/silverpush-says-its-not-in-t.html#more-453513" class="more-link">(more&hellip;)</a></p>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Nixon started the War on Drugs because he couldn&#039;t declare war on black people and hippies</title>
		<link>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/22/nixon-started-the-war-on-drugs.html</link>
		<comments>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/22/nixon-started-the-war-on-drugs.html#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Tue, 22 Mar 2016 07:19:01 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Cory Doctorow]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Post]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[drugs]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[gop]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[History]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[politics]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[race]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[the sucker was simple and plain]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[usausaua]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[war on drugs]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[war on some drugs]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://boingboing.net/?p=453509</guid>
		
		

		<description><![CDATA[<p><img width="486" height="307" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/800px-Elvis-nixon-1.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="800px-Elvis-nixon" srcset="http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/800px-Elvis-nixon-1.jpg?resize=300%2C190 300w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/800px-Elvis-nixon-1.jpg?w=486 486w" sizes="(max-width: 486px) 100vw, 486px" /></p><p>
Nixon aide/Watergate jailbird John Ehrlichman confessed to Dan Baum that Richard Nixon started the War on Drugs because "We knew we couldn’t make it illegal to be either against the war or black, but by getting the public to associate the hippies with marijuana and blacks with heroin, and then criminalizing both heavily, we could disrupt those communities."
 <a href="http://boingboing.net/2016/03/22/nixon-started-the-war-on-drugs.html#more-453509" class="more-link">(more&hellip;)</a></p>]]></description>
    <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><img width="486" height="307" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/800px-Elvis-nixon-1.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="800px-Elvis-nixon" srcset="http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/800px-Elvis-nixon-1.jpg?resize=300%2C190 300w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/800px-Elvis-nixon-1.jpg?w=486 486w" sizes="(max-width: 486px) 100vw, 486px" /></p><p>
Nixon aide/Watergate jailbird John Ehrlichman confessed to Dan Baum that Richard Nixon started the War on Drugs because "We knew we couldn’t make it illegal to be either against the war or black, but by getting the public to associate the hippies with marijuana and blacks with heroin, and then criminalizing both heavily, we could disrupt those communities."
 <a href="http://boingboing.net/2016/03/22/nixon-started-the-war-on-drugs.html#more-453509" class="more-link">(more&hellip;)</a></p>]]></content:encoded>
