		<title>Nixon started the War on Drugs because he couldn&#039;t declare war on black people and hippies</title>
		<link>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/22/nixon-started-the-war-on-drugs.html</link>
		<comments>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/22/nixon-started-the-war-on-drugs.html#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Tue, 22 Mar 2016 07:19:01 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Cory Doctorow]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Post]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[drugs]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[gop]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[History]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[politics]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[race]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[the sucker was simple and plain]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[usausaua]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[war on drugs]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[war on some drugs]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://boingboing.net/?p=453509</guid>
		
		

		<description><![CDATA[<p><img width="486" height="307" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/800px-Elvis-nixon-1.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="800px-Elvis-nixon" srcset="http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/800px-Elvis-nixon-1.jpg?resize=300%2C190 300w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/800px-Elvis-nixon-1.jpg?w=486 486w" sizes="(max-width: 486px) 100vw, 486px" /></p><p>
Nixon aide/Watergate jailbird John Ehrlichman confessed to Dan Baum that Richard Nixon started the War on Drugs because "We knew we couldn’t make it illegal to be either against the war or black, but by getting the public to associate the hippies with marijuana and blacks with heroin, and then criminalizing both heavily, we could disrupt those communities."
 <a href="http://boingboing.net/2016/03/22/nixon-started-the-war-on-drugs.html#more-453509" class="more-link">(more&hellip;)</a></p>]]></description>
    <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><img width="486" height="307" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/800px-Elvis-nixon-1.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="800px-Elvis-nixon" srcset="http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/800px-Elvis-nixon-1.jpg?resize=300%2C190 300w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/800px-Elvis-nixon-1.jpg?w=486 486w" sizes="(max-width: 486px) 100vw, 486px" /></p><p>
Nixon aide/Watergate jailbird John Ehrlichman confessed to Dan Baum that Richard Nixon started the War on Drugs because "We knew we couldn’t make it illegal to be either against the war or black, but by getting the public to associate the hippies with marijuana and blacks with heroin, and then criminalizing both heavily, we could disrupt those communities."
 <a href="http://boingboing.net/2016/03/22/nixon-started-the-war-on-drugs.html#more-453509" class="more-link">(more&hellip;)</a></p>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Anti-DRM demonstrators picket W3C meeting</title>
		<link>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/22/anti-drm-demonstrators-picket.html</link>
		<comments>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/22/anti-drm-demonstrators-picket.html#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Tue, 22 Mar 2016 07:10:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Cory Doctorow]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Post]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[1201]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[apollo]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[Copyfight]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[drm]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[eff]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[the web we want]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[W3C]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[war on general purpose computers]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://boingboing.net/?p=453506</guid>
		
		

		<description><![CDATA[<p><img width="1000" height="563" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/oi000093.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="OLYMPUS DIGITAL CAMERA" srcset="http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/oi000093.jpg?resize=300%2C169 300w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/oi000093.jpg?resize=600%2C338 600w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/oi000093.jpg?resize=768%2C432 768w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/oi000093.jpg?resize=930%2C524 930w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/oi000093.jpg?w=1000 1000w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /></p><p>
The World Wide Web Consortium, the decades old champion of the open Web, let down many of its biggest supporters when it decided to cater to Hollywood by <a href="https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2016/01/you-cant-destroy-village-save-it-w3c-vs-drm-round-two">standardizing DRM</a> as part of the spec for HTML5.
 <a href="http://boingboing.net/2016/03/22/anti-drm-demonstrators-picket.html#more-453506" class="more-link">(more&hellip;)</a></p>]]></description>
    <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><img width="1000" height="563" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/oi000093.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="OLYMPUS DIGITAL CAMERA" srcset="http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/oi000093.jpg?resize=300%2C169 300w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/oi000093.jpg?resize=600%2C338 600w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/oi000093.jpg?resize=768%2C432 768w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/oi000093.jpg?resize=930%2C524 930w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/oi000093.jpg?w=1000 1000w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /></p><p>
The World Wide Web Consortium, the decades old champion of the open Web, let down many of its biggest supporters when it decided to cater to Hollywood by <a href="https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2016/01/you-cant-destroy-village-save-it-w3c-vs-drm-round-two">standardizing DRM</a> as part of the spec for HTML5.
 <a href="http://boingboing.net/2016/03/22/anti-drm-demonstrators-picket.html#more-453506" class="more-link">(more&hellip;)</a></p>]]></content:encoded>

		<description><![CDATA[<p><img width="1500" height="885" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/thumb.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="thumb" srcset="http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/thumb.jpg?resize=300%2C177 300w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/thumb.jpg?resize=600%2C354 600w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/thumb.jpg?resize=768%2C453 768w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/thumb.jpg?resize=930%2C549 930w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/thumb.jpg?w=1500 1500w" sizes="(max-width: 1500px) 100vw, 1500px" /></p><p>

 <a href="http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/student-loan-garnisheeing-topp.html#more-453484" class="more-link">(more&hellip;)</a></p>]]></description>

		<title>FBI may not need Apple&#039;s help with that iPhone after all, nevermind, maybe</title>
		<link>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/fbi-may-not-need-apples-help.html</link>
		<comments>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/fbi-may-not-need-apples-help.html#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Tue, 22 Mar 2016 05:28:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Xeni Jardin]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Post]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[#applevsfbi]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[#fbivsapple]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[apple]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[encryption]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[fbi]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[iphone]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[war on crypto]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://boingboing.net/?p=453463</guid>
		
		

		<description><![CDATA[<p><img width="2000" height="1428" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/RTX28SQV.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="NYPD officer across the street from Apple&#039;s 5th Ave. store, NYC, March 11, 2016. REUTERS" srcset="http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/RTX28SQV.jpg?resize=300%2C214 300w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/RTX28SQV.jpg?resize=600%2C428 600w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/RTX28SQV.jpg?resize=768%2C548 768w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/RTX28SQV.jpg?resize=930%2C664 930w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/RTX28SQV.jpg?w=2000 2000w" sizes="(max-width: 2000px) 100vw, 2000px" /></p><p>In a surprising turn of events, the U.S. government on Monday paused its battle with Apple over an iPhone, and what may be its greater goal of mandating “backdoors” in consumer encryption. On Monday afternoon, the Justice Department told a judge it needs a couple weeks to try 'new' ways of accessing whatever may be on the device, without Apple's help--and with an assist from unnamed experts from outside the agency. </p><p>

 <a href="http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/fbi-may-not-need-apples-help.html#more-453463" class="more-link">(more&hellip;)</a></p>]]></description>
    <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><img width="2000" height="1428" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/RTX28SQV.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="NYPD officer across the street from Apple&#039;s 5th Ave. store, NYC, March 11, 2016. REUTERS" srcset="http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/RTX28SQV.jpg?resize=300%2C214 300w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/RTX28SQV.jpg?resize=600%2C428 600w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/RTX28SQV.jpg?resize=768%2C548 768w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/RTX28SQV.jpg?resize=930%2C664 930w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/RTX28SQV.jpg?w=2000 2000w" sizes="(max-width: 2000px) 100vw, 2000px" /></p><p>In a surprising turn of events, the U.S. government on Monday paused its battle with Apple over an iPhone, and what may be its greater goal of mandating “backdoors” in consumer encryption. On Monday afternoon, the Justice Department told a judge it needs a couple weeks to try 'new' ways of accessing whatever may be on the device, without Apple's help--and with an assist from unnamed experts from outside the agency. </p><p>

 <a href="http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/fbi-may-not-need-apples-help.html#more-453463" class="more-link">(more&hellip;)</a></p>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>American Porn Psycho</title>
		<link>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/american-porn-psycho.html</link>
		<comments>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/american-porn-psycho.html#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Tue, 22 Mar 2016 00:20:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Rob Beschizza]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Post]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[crimes]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[james deen]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[porn]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://boingboing.net/?p=453457</guid>
		
		

		<description><![CDATA[<p><img width="800" height="450" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/deen.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="© Glenn Francis, www.PacificProDigital.com" srcset="http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/deen.jpg?resize=300%2C169 300w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/deen.jpg?resize=600%2C338 600w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/deen.jpg?resize=768%2C432 768w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/deen.jpg?w=800 800w" sizes="(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px" /></p><p>After porn actress Stoya <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/culture/2015/dec/04/how-stoya-took-on-james-deen-and-broke-the-porn-industrys-silence">claimed that James Deen raped her</a>, nine other women came forward with stories of his violent misdeeds. With <a href="http://mic.com/articles/133343/3-months-later-here-s-what-the-porn-industry-thinks-of-james-deen#.gaomVJt0Y">Deen's career not quite over</a>, Zak Smith <a href="https://medium.com/@zaksmith_/james-deen-cookie-monster-c05490730609#.flguepdpp">profiled him for "A Very Old And Important American Magazine"</a>—whose lawyers got cold feet about the results. So on <em>Medium</em> it goes. <a href="http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/american-porn-psycho.html#more-453457" class="more-link">(more&hellip;)</a></p>]]></description>
    <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><img width="800" height="450" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/deen.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="© Glenn Francis, www.PacificProDigital.com" srcset="http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/deen.jpg?resize=300%2C169 300w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/deen.jpg?resize=600%2C338 600w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/deen.jpg?resize=768%2C432 768w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/deen.jpg?w=800 800w" sizes="(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px" /></p><p>After porn actress Stoya <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/culture/2015/dec/04/how-stoya-took-on-james-deen-and-broke-the-porn-industrys-silence">claimed that James Deen raped her</a>, nine other women came forward with stories of his violent misdeeds. With <a href="http://mic.com/articles/133343/3-months-later-here-s-what-the-porn-industry-thinks-of-james-deen#.gaomVJt0Y">Deen's career not quite over</a>, Zak Smith <a href="https://medium.com/@zaksmith_/james-deen-cookie-monster-c05490730609#.flguepdpp">profiled him for "A Very Old And Important American Magazine"</a>—whose lawyers got cold feet about the results. So on <em>Medium</em> it goes. <a href="http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/american-porn-psycho.html#more-453457" class="more-link">(more&hellip;)</a></p>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Gross Video: What does human flesh taste like?</title>
		<link>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/video-what-does-human-flesh-t.html</link>
		<comments>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/video-what-does-human-flesh-t.html#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Mar 2016 23:24:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[David Pescovitz]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Video]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[cannibalism]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[Food]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://boingboing.net/?p=453445</guid>
		
		

		<description><![CDATA[<img width="541" height="290" src="http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/screenshot-11.jpg?fit=541%2C290" class="attachment-medium size-medium wp-post-image" alt="screenshot" srcset="http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/screenshot-11.jpg?resize=300%2C161 300w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/screenshot-11.jpg?w=541 541w" sizes="(max-width: 541px) 100vw, 541px" /> <p> <P>
<em><strong>Not for the squeamish!</strong></em>
<P>
What might human flesh taste like? It's apparently illegal to eat people, even yourself, so Greg Foot of the BBC's Brit Lab settled for having a tiny morsel of his own thigh removed and cooked so he could sniff it, and speculate.  <em>(<a href="https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCdsOTr6SmDrxuWE7sJFrkhQ">Brit Lab</a>, thanks <a href="http://www.iftf.org/seanness/">Sean Ness</a>!)</em>
<P>

<P>
<img src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/screenshot-11.jpg" alt="screenshot" width="541" height="290" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-453448" />]]></description>
    <content:encoded><![CDATA[<img width="541" height="290" src="http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/screenshot-11.jpg?fit=541%2C290" class="attachment-medium size-medium wp-post-image" alt="screenshot" srcset="http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/screenshot-11.jpg?resize=300%2C161 300w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/screenshot-11.jpg?w=541 541w" sizes="(max-width: 541px) 100vw, 541px" /> <p> <P>
<em><strong>Not for the squeamish!</strong></em>
<P>
What might human flesh taste like? It's apparently illegal to eat people, even yourself, so Greg Foot of the BBC's Brit Lab settled for having a tiny morsel of his own thigh removed and cooked so he could sniff it, and speculate.  <em>(<a href="https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCdsOTr6SmDrxuWE7sJFrkhQ">Brit Lab</a>, thanks <a href="http://www.iftf.org/seanness/">Sean Ness</a>!)</em>

		<title>Apple releases iOS 9.3, with fix for a big iMessage security flaw</title>
		<link>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/apple-releases-ios-9-3-with-f.html</link>
		<comments>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/apple-releases-ios-9-3-with-f.html#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Mar 2016 22:45:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Xeni Jardin]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Post]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[apple]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[ios]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://boingboing.net/?p=453440</guid>
		
		

		<description><![CDATA[<p><img width="670" height="447" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/apple-icloud-encryption.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="apple-icloud-encryption" srcset="http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/apple-icloud-encryption.jpg?resize=300%2C200 300w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/apple-icloud-encryption.jpg?resize=600%2C400 600w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/apple-icloud-encryption.jpg?w=670 670w" sizes="(max-width: 670px) 100vw, 670px" /></p><p>
As part of its big <a href="https://www.apple.com/iphone-se/">iPhone</a>/<a href="https://www.apple.com/ipad-pro/">iPad</a> launch event today in Cupertino, Apple also released a software update that fixes a flaw which made it possible for iCloud-stored images or video sent via iMessage to be decrypted by third parties. Today's iOS update also adds a number of cool new features. </p><p>
 <a href="http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/apple-releases-ios-9-3-with-f.html#more-453440" class="more-link">(more&hellip;)</a></p>]]></description>
    <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><img width="670" height="447" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/apple-icloud-encryption.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="apple-icloud-encryption" srcset="http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/apple-icloud-encryption.jpg?resize=300%2C200 300w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/apple-icloud-encryption.jpg?resize=600%2C400 600w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/apple-icloud-encryption.jpg?w=670 670w" sizes="(max-width: 670px) 100vw, 670px" /></p><p>
As part of its big <a href="https://www.apple.com/iphone-se/">iPhone</a>/<a href="https://www.apple.com/ipad-pro/">iPad</a> launch event today in Cupertino, Apple also released a software update that fixes a flaw which made it possible for iCloud-stored images or video sent via iMessage to be decrypted by third parties. Today's iOS update also adds a number of cool new features. </p><p>

		<item>
		<title>Paris terrorists used disposable burner phones to hide plans. No evidence of encryption.</title>
		<link>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/paris-terrorists-used-disposab.html</link>
		<comments>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/paris-terrorists-used-disposab.html#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Mar 2016 22:36:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Xeni Jardin]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Post]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[crypto]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[encryption]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[paris]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://boingboing.net/?p=453429</guid>
		
		

		<description><![CDATA[<p><img width="670" height="447" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/burner-phones.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="burner-phones" srcset="http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/burner-phones.jpg?resize=300%2C200 300w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/burner-phones.jpg?resize=600%2C400 600w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/burner-phones.jpg?w=670 670w" sizes="(max-width: 670px) 100vw, 670px" /></p><p>"Everywhere they went, the attackers left behind their throwaway phones." <p>Buried in the <em>New York Times</em> story Mark <a href="http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/nyt-if-you-see-gibberish-on.html">poked fun at earlier for its Crypto Panic vibe</a>, a confirmation of sorts that there's really no evidence the terrorists used crypto at all. There is lots of evidence they used throwaway burner phones to evade detection while planning mass murder. Again, no evidence <a href="http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/nyt-if-you-see-gibberish-on.html">encryption</a>, none, period. This is significant because these attacks, and similar ones that followed, are at the core of an anti-encryption charm offensive by the FBI and Department of Justice, now targeted at Apple's iPhone.<p>
<p>
<em>Ars Technica</em> <a href="http://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2016/03/paris-terrorist-attacks-burner-phones-not-encryption/">rehashes</a> the details of the <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/20/world/europe/a-view-of-isiss-evolution-in-new-details-of-paris-attacks.html">NYT piece</a> and then <a href="http://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2016/03/paris-terrorist-attacks-burner-phones-not-encryption/">puts it plainly</a>:

<p>

<blockquote><p>Until we have stronger evidence to the contrary, it seems likely that encryption played little or no part in the Paris terrorist attacks.<p>
</blockquote>

<p>


<p>
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">The NYT story on the Paris attackers makes just as much (if not more) sense if you replace &quot;encryption&quot; with &quot;magic&quot; <a href="https://t.co/1ATUU1fzRM">pic.twitter.com/1ATUU1fzRM</a></p>&mdash; Christopher Soghoian (@csoghoian) <a href="https://twitter.com/csoghoian/status/711619683997323264">March 20, 2016</a></blockquote>
<script async src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script>]]></description>
    <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><img width="670" height="447" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/burner-phones.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="burner-phones" srcset="http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/burner-phones.jpg?resize=300%2C200 300w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/burner-phones.jpg?resize=600%2C400 600w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/burner-phones.jpg?w=670 670w" sizes="(max-width: 670px) 100vw, 670px" /></p><p>"Everywhere they went, the attackers left behind their throwaway phones." <p>Buried in the <em>New York Times</em> story Mark <a href="http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/nyt-if-you-see-gibberish-on.html">poked fun at earlier for its Crypto Panic vibe</a>, a confirmation of sorts that there's really no evidence the terrorists used crypto at all. There is lots of evidence they used throwaway burner phones to evade detection while planning mass murder. Again, no evidence <a href="http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/nyt-if-you-see-gibberish-on.html">encryption</a>, none, period. This is significant because these attacks, and similar ones that followed, are at the core of an anti-encryption charm offensive by the FBI and Department of Justice, now targeted at Apple's iPhone.<p>
<p>
<em>Ars Technica</em> <a href="http://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2016/03/paris-terrorist-attacks-burner-phones-not-encryption/">rehashes</a> the details of the <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/20/world/europe/a-view-of-isiss-evolution-in-new-details-of-paris-attacks.html">NYT piece</a> and then <a href="http://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2016/03/paris-terrorist-attacks-burner-phones-not-encryption/">puts it plainly</a>:

<p>

<blockquote><p>Until we have stronger evidence to the contrary, it seems likely that encryption played little or no part in the Paris terrorist attacks.<p>
</blockquote>

<p>


<p>
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">The NYT story on the Paris attackers makes just as much (if not more) sense if you replace &quot;encryption&quot; with &quot;magic&quot; <a href="https://t.co/1ATUU1fzRM">pic.twitter.com/1ATUU1fzRM</a></p>&mdash; Christopher Soghoian (@csoghoian) <a href="https://twitter.com/csoghoian/status/711619683997323264">March 20, 2016</a></blockquote>
<script async src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script>]]></content:encoded>
		

		<wfw:commentRss>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/paris-terrorists-used-disposab.html/feed</wfw:commentRss>

		<item>
		<title>An animated series about women who dared defy history</title>
		<link>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/an-animated-series-about-women.html</link>
		<comments>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/an-animated-series-about-women.html#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Mar 2016 22:06:43 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Rob Beschizza]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Post]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[Video]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[animation]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[History]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[women]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://boingboing.net/?p=453425</guid>
		
		

		<description><![CDATA[<img width="540" height="405" src="http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/635930333258573548-MurasakiWorldShot.png?fit=540%2C405" class="attachment-medium size-medium wp-post-image" alt="635930333258573548-MurasakiWorldShot" srcset="http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/635930333258573548-MurasakiWorldShot.png?resize=300%2C225 300w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/635930333258573548-MurasakiWorldShot.png?w=540 540w" sizes="(max-width: 540px) 100vw, 540px" /> <p> 
<p><em>Ordinary Women: Daring to Defy History</em> is a video series about women overlooked by history <a href="https://www.seedandspark.com/studio/ordinary-women#story">raising production funds at crowdfunding site Seed & Spark</a>. Creators Anita Sarkeesian, Laura Hudson (recently of Boing Boing and Offworld) and Elizabeth Aultman plan to feature Murasaki Shikibu, credited as the first modern novelist, 19th-century computer pioneer Ada Lovelace, womens' rights advocate Emma Goldman and others.

<p>Unusually for a crowdfunded production, <a href="http://www.bustle.com/articles/146942-ordinary-women-crowdfunding-campaign-from-anita-sarkeesian-feminist-frequency-wants-to-give-ladies-in-history">the series will be lavishly animated, reports Bustle</a>, creating a work of art in its own right.

<blockquote><p>It's an exploration of women throughout history who have decimated gender stereotypes and contributed to humanity in truly impactful ways. The series will seek to remind us not only that these kinds of women — the rabble-rousers, the undercover reporters, the activists, the pirates — are extraordinary individuals, but also that women doing extraordinary things is actually quite ordinary. And that's a good thing. Here's why.
<p>
Women kicking ass and taking names shouldn't come as too much of a surprise, because we've been here all along, propping up society with our accomplishments. Unfortunately, the telling of history has a way of being whitewashed, male-focused, and more, excluding the contributions of far too many women, people of color, LGBTQ people, and other marginalized groups. With this new video series, Feminist Frequency hopes to address that glaring imbalance by bringing to life the stories of some of history's most rebellious and remarkable women.
</blockquote>

<p>USA Today reports that <a href="http://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/gaming/2016/03/08/video-game-critic-turns-spotlight-women-history/81476886/">the creators hope it will inspire more women.</a>

<blockquote>
“We want to normalize these women in history,” says Sarkeesian. “These woman doing these extraordinary things are ordinary in and of themselves — that women can do this.”</blockquote>

<p>They also wrote an article at Time <a href="http://time.com/4248910/women-in-history/">about the need to rewrite the historical record that often obscures womens' achievements</a>.

<blockquote>…take a deeper look into history, and you’ll find countless women who did incredible things that weren’t recognized in their time—or even in ours. The erasure of women from history is two-fold: not only are we discouraged or punished for stepping outside the limited roles offered to us, but when we do achieve great things despite the odds, our accomplishments are often diminished, ignored or credited to men.

</blockquote>


<p><a href="https://www.seedandspark.com/studio/ordinary-women#story">Ordinary Women: Daring to Defy History.</a> [Seed & Spark]]]></description>
    <content:encoded><![CDATA[<img width="540" height="405" src="http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/635930333258573548-MurasakiWorldShot.png?fit=540%2C405" class="attachment-medium size-medium wp-post-image" alt="635930333258573548-MurasakiWorldShot" srcset="http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/635930333258573548-MurasakiWorldShot.png?resize=300%2C225 300w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/635930333258573548-MurasakiWorldShot.png?w=540 540w" sizes="(max-width: 540px) 100vw, 540px" /> <p> 
<p><em>Ordinary Women: Daring to Defy History</em> is a video series about women overlooked by history <a href="https://www.seedandspark.com/studio/ordinary-women#story">raising production funds at crowdfunding site Seed & Spark</a>. Creators Anita Sarkeesian, Laura Hudson (recently of Boing Boing and Offworld) and Elizabeth Aultman plan to feature Murasaki Shikibu, credited as the first modern novelist, 19th-century computer pioneer Ada Lovelace, womens' rights advocate Emma Goldman and others.

<p>Unusually for a crowdfunded production, <a href="http://www.bustle.com/articles/146942-ordinary-women-crowdfunding-campaign-from-anita-sarkeesian-feminist-frequency-wants-to-give-ladies-in-history">the series will be lavishly animated, reports Bustle</a>, creating a work of art in its own right.

<blockquote><p>It's an exploration of women throughout history who have decimated gender stereotypes and contributed to humanity in truly impactful ways. The series will seek to remind us not only that these kinds of women — the rabble-rousers, the undercover reporters, the activists, the pirates — are extraordinary individuals, but also that women doing extraordinary things is actually quite ordinary. And that's a good thing. Here's why.
<p>
Women kicking ass and taking names shouldn't come as too much of a surprise, because we've been here all along, propping up society with our accomplishments. Unfortunately, the telling of history has a way of being whitewashed, male-focused, and more, excluding the contributions of far too many women, people of color, LGBTQ people, and other marginalized groups. With this new video series, Feminist Frequency hopes to address that glaring imbalance by bringing to life the stories of some of history's most rebellious and remarkable women.
</blockquote>

<p>USA Today reports that <a href="http://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/gaming/2016/03/08/video-game-critic-turns-spotlight-women-history/81476886/">the creators hope it will inspire more women.</a>

<blockquote>
“We want to normalize these women in history,” says Sarkeesian. “These woman doing these extraordinary things are ordinary in and of themselves — that women can do this.”</blockquote>

<p>They also wrote an article at Time <a href="http://time.com/4248910/women-in-history/">about the need to rewrite the historical record that often obscures womens' achievements</a>.

<blockquote>…take a deeper look into history, and you’ll find countless women who did incredible things that weren’t recognized in their time—or even in ours. The erasure of women from history is two-fold: not only are we discouraged or punished for stepping outside the limited roles offered to us, but when we do achieve great things despite the odds, our accomplishments are often diminished, ignored or credited to men.

</blockquote>


<p><a href="https://www.seedandspark.com/studio/ordinary-women#story">Ordinary Women: Daring to Defy History.</a> [Seed & Spark]]]></content:encoded>
		

		<wfw:commentRss>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/an-animated-series-about-women.html/feed</wfw:commentRss>

		<item>
		<title>Portable USB battery with Apple Lightning input port</title>
		<link>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/portable-usb-battery-with-appl.html</link>
		<comments>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/portable-usb-battery-with-appl.html#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Mar 2016 19:56:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Mark Frauenfelder]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Post]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[batteries]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[iphone]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://boingboing.net/?p=453420</guid>
		
		

		<description><![CDATA[<p><img width="600" height="424" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/aukey.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="aukey" srcset="http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/aukey.jpg?resize=300%2C212 300w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/aukey.jpg?w=600 600w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /></p><p>This is the <a href="http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/B00SV0R2NY/boingboing">first USB battery I've seen with a Lightning input port</a> (instead of a micro USB port). It's got 3600mAh and you can buy it for $8 when you use the YCOIWN27 coupon code at checkout.]]></description>
    <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><img width="600" height="424" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/aukey.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="aukey" srcset="http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/aukey.jpg?resize=300%2C212 300w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/aukey.jpg?w=600 600w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /></p><p>This is the <a href="http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/B00SV0R2NY/boingboing">first USB battery I've seen with a Lightning input port</a> (instead of a micro USB port). It's got 3600mAh and you can buy it for $8 when you use the YCOIWN27 coupon code at checkout.]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Three Awesome Drones For Every Budget</title>
		<link>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/three-awesome-drones-for-every.html</link>
		<comments>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/three-awesome-drones-for-every.html#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Mar 2016 19:38:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Boing Boing's Store]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Post]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[shop]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://boingboing.net/?p=453286</guid>
		
		

		<description><![CDATA[<p><img width="480" height="270" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/drone.gif" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="drone" /></p><p><span style="font-weight: 400">Drones are so hot right now. Plain old pictures from your human-height point of view, or videos taken from the ground are old news. Everyone’s shooting from the sky and you should too because the images are simply stunning. And now, no matter what your budget is, you can grab a drone and start flying today. </span></p><p style="text-align: center"><strong>Skeye Nano Drone w/ Camera</strong></p><p><img class="aligncenter" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/35e913018f19821c84f8087492fb18cdab49a69a_main_hero_image-4.jpg" alt="" width="630" height="473" /></p><p><span style="font-weight: 400">You don’t have to be Maverick or Goose to operate a drone. The Skeye Nano is so small but so smart, it calibrates itself every time it hits the air so you can pilot it easily </span><a href="https://store.boingboing.net/sales/skeye-nano-drone-with-camera?utm_source=boingboing.net&amp;utm_medium=referral&amp;utm_campaign=skeye-nano-drone-with-camera"><span style="font-weight: 400">for 27% off</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400">. It’s so small it can navigate through the narrowest of spaces for stellar video shots and even has built-in LED lights for night rides. From beginner, intermediate to expert, you can take yourself to flight school with this mini powerhouse.</span></p><p style="text-align: center"><strong>Hubsan H501S X4 FPV Brushless Drone </strong></p><p><img class="aligncenter" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/f5f907c5823542e4b31e35060a4e202d542b755b_main_hero_image-5.jpg" alt="" width="630" height="473" /></p><p><img class="aligncenter" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/2da17c35fa9ae1fd731cb2e6f14156af8e8ac7e9_main_hero_image-5.jpg" alt="" width="630" height="473" /></p><p><span style="font-weight: 400">For packing a bigger punch, the Hubsan FPV Brushless drone has advanced technology that allows it to follow the remote control user wherever you go. </span><a href="https://store.boingboing.net/sales/hubsan-h501s-x4-brushless-drone?utm_source=boingboing.net&amp;utm_medium=referral&amp;utm_campaign=hubsan-h501s-x4-brushless-drone"><span style="font-weight: 400">For 12% off</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400">, it captures real time HD video and flies up to twenty minutes on each charge. Its powerful, durable motors even have a headless mode so you can set it in one direction and let it run its course solo.</span></p><p style="text-align: center"><strong>Code Black Drone w/ HD Camera</strong></p><p><img class="aligncenter" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/f57d195272cfa0ae1d57b1e26069ff45867ca3cb_main_hero_image-4.jpg" alt="" width="630" height="473" /></p><p><span style="font-weight: 400">The best selling drone of all time, however, is the Code Black. From the moment you take it out of the box, it’s ready to fly. This popular favorite is </span><a href="https://store.boingboing.net/sales/the-limited-edition-black-hawk-drone-hd-camera?utm_source=boingboing.net&amp;utm_medium=referral&amp;utm_campaign=the-limited-edition-black-hawk-drone-hd-camera"><span style="font-weight: 400">64% off right now</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400"> and offers a six axis control system that makes every flight nice and stable. It can flip, turn and zip around to capture any kind of HD image you want from any angle. And like all great drones, it’s got both beginner and advanced settings so you can fly at your own pace.</span></p><p><br /><span style="font-weight: 400">Any way you fly, one of these drones has you covered. Once you see those little propellers up in the sky then check out the sweet video footage from a bird’s eye view, you’ll be hooked. </span></p>]]></description>
    <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><img width="480" height="270" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/drone.gif" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="drone" /></p><p><span style="font-weight: 400">Drones are so hot right now. 		<item>
		<title>Book Review: &#039;Unhappenings&#039; is a fantastic time travel novel</title>
		<link>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/unhappenings-a-fantastic-time.html</link>
		<comments>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/unhappenings-a-fantastic-time.html#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Mar 2016 18:52:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Jason Weisberger]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Post]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[books]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[Time Travel]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://boingboing.net/?p=453401</guid>
		
		

		<description><![CDATA[<p><img width="324" height="499" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/51kG2dsp-PL._SX322_BO1204203200_.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="51kG2dsp-PL._SX322_BO1,204,203,200_" srcset="http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/51kG2dsp-PL._SX322_BO1204203200_.jpg?resize=300%2C462 300w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/51kG2dsp-PL._SX322_BO1204203200_.jpg?w=324 324w" sizes="(max-width: 324px) 100vw, 324px" /></p><P>
Edward Aubry's <a href="http://amzn.to/1SdtODT"><em>Unhappenings</em></a> is a smart and satisfying time travel novel. I love stories about paradox created by folks moving around in time, and this novel has it in spades.
<p>
At age 14 Nigel Walden starts to experience the titular <em>Unhappenings</em>, mundane things in his life seem to random change. The color of his bicycle changes, and conversations he thought he had never occurred, but then his first girlfriend disappears as if she never existed. Every time Nigel gets close to someone, he seemingly causes a catastrophe that leaves the relationship never having happened. As he reaches college, Nigel realizes he must be involved in some sort of time travel. Things only get more complicated.
<p>
Aubry's writing is clear, simple and telling. I felt Nigel's emotional traumas and the difficulty of growing up so different, the slower pace of this novel is well employed. 
<P>
<a href="http://amzn.to/1SdtODT"><em>Unhappenings</em> by Edward Aubry</a> via Amazon]]></description>
    <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><img width="324" height="499" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/51kG2dsp-PL._SX322_BO1204203200_.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="51kG2dsp-PL._SX322_BO1,204,203,200_" srcset="http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/51kG2dsp-PL._SX322_BO1204203200_.jpg?resize=300%2C462 300w, http://i1.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/51kG2dsp-PL._SX322_BO1204203200_.jpg?w=324 324w" sizes="(max-width: 324px) 100vw, 324px" /></p><P>
Edward Aubry's <a href="http://amzn.to/1SdtODT"><em>Unhappenings</em></a> is a smart and satisfying time travel novel. I love stories about paradox created by folks moving around in time, and this novel has it in spades.
<p>
At age 14 Nigel Walden starts to experience the titular <em>Unhappenings</em>, mundane things in his life seem to random change. The color of his bicycle changes, and conversations he thought he had never occurred, but then his first girlfriend disappears as if she never existed. Every time Nigel gets close to someone, he seemingly causes a catastrophe that leaves the relationship never having happened. As he reaches college, Nigel realizes he must be involved in some sort of time travel. Things only get more complicated.
<p>
Aubry's writing is clear, simple and telling. I felt Nigel's emotional traumas and the difficulty of growing up so different, the slower pace of this novel is well employed. 
<P>
<a href="http://amzn.to/1SdtODT"><em>Unhappenings</em> by Edward Aubry</a> via Amazon]]></content:encoded>
		

		<wfw:commentRss>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/unhappenings-a-fantastic-time.html/feed</wfw:commentRss>

		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Mar 2016 18:45:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Mark Frauenfelder]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Post]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[fucking magnets]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://boingboing.net/?p=453402</guid>
		
		

		<description><![CDATA[<p><img width="480" height="270" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/jR5Q0z.gif" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="jR5Q0z" /></p>https://youtu.be/IANBoybVApQ
<p>Destin of the YouTube show <a href="https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC6107grRI4m0o2-emgoDnAA">Smarter Every Day</a> went to a company called Polymagnets and learns how they are making programmable magnets that can behave like springs or door latches. ]]></description>

		<item>
		<title>NYT: If you see weird text on a computer screen, might be terrorist encryption software</title>
		<link>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/nyt-if-you-see-gibberish-on.html</link>
		<comments>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/nyt-if-you-see-gibberish-on.html#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Mar 2016 18:26:33 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Mark Frauenfelder]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Post]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[crypto]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[Foolishness]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[terrorism]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[war on crypto]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://boingboing.net/?p=453388</guid>
		
		

		<description><![CDATA[<p><img width="600" height="158" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/CeFFWtxUEAAJ9BA.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="CeFFWtxUEAAJ9BA" srcset="http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/CeFFWtxUEAAJ9BA.jpg?resize=300%2C79 300w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/CeFFWtxUEAAJ9BA.jpg?w=600 600w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /></p>From a March 19, 2016 <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/20/world/europe/a-view-of-isiss-evolution-in-new-details-of-paris-attacks.html">New York Times</a> article:

<blockquote><p>One of the terrorists pulled out a laptop, propping it open against the wall, said the 40-year-old woman. When the laptop powered on, she saw a line of gibberish across the screen: “It was bizarre — he was looking at a bunch of lines, like lines of code. There was no image, no Internet,” she said. <strong>Her description matches the look of certain encryption software</strong>, which ISIS claims to have used during the Paris attacks.</blockquote>

<p>To summarize, if you see something on someone's computer screen that fits the description below, the person with the computer could be an ISIS terrorist!

<ol>
<li>It looks like "a line of gibberish across the screen."</li>


	<li>It's "a bunch of lines, like lines of code."</li>


	<li>There's "no image."</li>


	<li>There's "no Internet."</li>
</ol>



<p>It's good to know the spirit of <a href="http://www.salon.com/2015/04/30/jon_stewart_smacks_down_judith_miller_you_drove_us_into_the_devastating_iraq_war/">Judith Miller</a> lives on at the <em>Times</em>! 

<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">The NYT story on the Paris attackers makes just as much (if not more) sense if you replace &quot;encryption&quot; with &quot;magic&quot; <a href="https://t.co/1ATUU1fzRM">pic.twitter.com/1ATUU1fzRM</a></p>&mdash; Christopher Soghoian (@csoghoian) <a href="https://twitter.com/csoghoian/status/711619683997323264">March 20, 2016</a></blockquote>
<script async src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script>

<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">How the fuck has <a href="https://twitter.com/nytimes">@nytimes</a> not edited this utter shit? <a href="https://t.co/C884P1r1p7">pic.twitter.com/C884P1r1p7</a></p>&mdash; Internet of Shit (@internetofshit) <a href="https://twitter.com/internetofshit/status/711926515366100993">March 21, 2016</a></blockquote>
<script async src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script>

<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en"><p lang="en" dir="ltr"><a href="https://twitter.com/internetofshit">@internetofshit</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/nytimes">@nytimes</a> Look im using encryption software! <a href="https://t.co/RmnAGMEgGH">pic.twitter.com/RmnAGMEgGH</a></p>&mdash; Rob (@robatcisco) <a href="https://twitter.com/robatcisco/status/711926883517005824">March 21, 2016</a></blockquote>
<script async src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script>


<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en"><p lang="en" dir="ltr"><a href="https://twitter.com/internetofshit">@internetofshit</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/nytimes">@nytimes</a> Encryption for some people: <a href="https://t.co/zKJhgFS7JS">pic.twitter.com/zKJhgFS7JS</a></p>&mdash; Miguel Esquirol (@miguelesquirol) <a href="https://twitter.com/miguelesquirol/status/711927249776214016">March 21, 2016</a></blockquote>
<script async src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script>]]></description>
    <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><img width="600" height="158" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/CeFFWtxUEAAJ9BA.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="CeFFWtxUEAAJ9BA" srcset="http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/CeFFWtxUEAAJ9BA.jpg?resize=300%2C79 300w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/CeFFWtxUEAAJ9BA.jpg?w=600 600w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /></p>From a March 19, 2016 <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/20/world/europe/a-view-of-isiss-evolution-in-new-details-of-paris-attacks.html">New York Times</a> article:

<blockquote><p>One of the terrorists pulled out a laptop, propping it open against the wall, said the 40-year-old woman. When the laptop powered on, she saw a line of gibberish across the screen: “It was bizarre — he was looking at a bunch of lines, like lines of code. There was no image, no Internet,” she said. <strong>Her description matches the look of certain encryption software</strong>, which ISIS claims to have used during the Paris attacks.</blockquote>

<p>To summarize, if you see something on someone's computer screen that fits the description below, the person with the computer could be an ISIS terrorist!

<ol>
<li>It looks like "a line of gibberish across the screen."</li>


	<li>It's "a bunch of lines, like lines of code."</li>


	<li>There's "no image."</li>


	<li>There's "no Internet."</li>
</ol>



<p>It's good to know the spirit of <a href="http://www.salon.com/2015/04/30/jon_stewart_smacks_down_judith_miller_you_drove_us_into_the_devastating_iraq_war/">Judith Miller</a> lives on at the <em>Times</em>! 

<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">The NYT story on the Paris attackers makes just as much (if not more) sense if you replace &quot;encryption&quot; with &quot;magic&quot; <a href="https://t.co/1ATUU1fzRM">pic.twitter.com/1ATUU1fzRM</a></p>&mdash; Christopher Soghoian (@csoghoian) <a href="https://twitter.com/csoghoian/status/711619683997323264">March 20, 2016</a></blockquote>
<script async src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script>

<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">How the fuck has <a href="https://twitter.com/nytimes">@nytimes</a> not edited this utter shit? <a href="https://t.co/C884P1r1p7">pic.twitter.com/C884P1r1p7</a></p>&mdash; Internet of Shit (@internetofshit) <a href="https://twitter.com/internetofshit/status/711926515366100993">March 21, 2016</a></blockquote>
<script async src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script>

<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en"><p lang="en" dir="ltr"><a href="https://twitter.com/internetofshit">@internetofshit</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/nytimes">@nytimes</a> Look im using encryption software! <a href="https://t.co/RmnAGMEgGH">pic.twitter.com/RmnAGMEgGH</a></p>&mdash; Rob (@robatcisco) <a href="https://twitter.com/robatcisco/status/711926883517005824">March 21, 2016</a></blockquote>
<script async src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script>


<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en"><p lang="en" dir="ltr"><a href="https://twitter.com/internetofshit">@internetofshit</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/nytimes">@nytimes</a> Encryption for some people: <a href="https://t.co/zKJhgFS7JS">pic.twitter.com/zKJhgFS7JS</a></p>&mdash; Miguel Esquirol (@miguelesquirol) <a href="https://twitter.com/miguelesquirol/status/711927249776214016">March 21, 2016</a></blockquote>

		<title>Review: &#039;Pee-wee&#039;s Big Holiday&#039; (loved it)</title>
		<link>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/review-pee-wees-big-holid.html</link>
		<comments>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/review-pee-wees-big-holid.html#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Mar 2016 17:31:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Jason Weisberger]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Post]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[Video]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[Entertainment]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[film]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[movies]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[paul reubens]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[pee-wee]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://boingboing.net/?p=453279</guid>
		
		

		<description><![CDATA[<img width="600" height="316" src="http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/NEBW62NGiiKXFD_1_a.jpg?fit=600%2C316" class="attachment-medium size-medium wp-post-image" alt="NEBW62NGiiKXFD_1_a" srcset="http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/NEBW62NGiiKXFD_1_a.jpg?resize=300%2C158 300w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/NEBW62NGiiKXFD_1_a.jpg?resize=600%2C316 600w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/NEBW62NGiiKXFD_1_a.jpg?resize=768%2C404 768w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/NEBW62NGiiKXFD_1_a.jpg?resize=930%2C489 930w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/NEBW62NGiiKXFD_1_a.jpg?w=1197 1197w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /> <p> <p>
Last night my eight-year-old daughter and I enjoyed <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aK3psQmIdnU"><em>Pee-wee's Big Holiday</em></a>. This is a fantastic return for <em>Pee-wee Herman</em>, and Paul Reubens has done a masterful job. Pee-wee's charm, innocence, and awesome moral compass are still keeping him out of trouble, despite a cast of delightfully troublesome characters that pop up along the way.</p><p>
 <a href="http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/review-pee-wees-big-holid.html#more-453279" class="more-link">(more&hellip;)</a></p>]]></description>
    <content:encoded><![CDATA[<img width="600" height="316" src="http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/NEBW62NGiiKXFD_1_a.jpg?fit=600%2C316" class="attachment-medium size-medium wp-post-image" alt="NEBW62NGiiKXFD_1_a" srcset="http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/NEBW62NGiiKXFD_1_a.jpg?resize=300%2C158 300w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/NEBW62NGiiKXFD_1_a.jpg?resize=600%2C316 600w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/NEBW62NGiiKXFD_1_a.jpg?resize=768%2C404 768w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/NEBW62NGiiKXFD_1_a.jpg?resize=930%2C489 930w, http://i2.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/NEBW62NGiiKXFD_1_a.jpg?w=1197 1197w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /> <p> <p>
Last night my eight-year-old daughter and I enjoyed <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aK3psQmIdnU"><em>Pee-wee's Big Holiday</em></a>. This is a fantastic return for <em>Pee-wee Herman</em>, and Paul Reubens has done a masterful job. Pee-wee's charm, innocence, and awesome moral compass are still keeping him out of trouble, despite a cast of delightfully troublesome characters that pop up along the way.</p><p>

		<item>
		<title>Shaman is bonkers and goofy and absurd – and grounded in reality</title>
		<link>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/shaman-is-bonkers-and-goofy-an.html</link>
		<comments>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/shaman-is-bonkers-and-goofy-an.html#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Mar 2016 17:11:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Wink]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Post]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[graphic novels]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://boingboing.net/?p=453382</guid>
		
		

		<description><![CDATA[<p><a href="http://winkbooks.net/post/141424962759/shaman-is-bonkers-and-goofy-and-absurd-and">See sample pages from this book at Wink.</a>

<p><em>“He’s the one who makes your whole world possible. This is a world of noble heroes, and savage villains. A world where men and women of great power die everyday. And the Shaman? The Shaman is the one who brings them back.”</em>

</p><p>Ben Kahn and Bruno Hidalgo’s <em><a href="http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/0989907686/thebooklab-20">Shaman Vol. 1</a></em> is, on its surface, an entertaining, fast-paced, self-deprecating story about a guy who raises the dead, his young daughter who wields magic from her mystical tattoos, and a teleporting former superhero-turned-sidekick who travel around bringing back to life those whom “the personification of life itself” tells them to. Along the way, they fight skeletons and Cosmic Guardians and giant green monsters, all the while throwing down quips and wisecracks and pop culture references. It’s fun stuff all around, pulling you in and making you laugh out loud. 

</p><p>But coursing underneath throughout the narrative is an examination of the concepts of right and wrong, good and evil, life and loss, and what it means to be a “family.” Ben Kahn’s storytelling works in the gray areas where nothing is clean cut, and everything, therefore, becomes far more interesting. What could easily be flat, one-dimensional characters are, here, complex, multi-dimensional beings whose motivations and choices are constantly examined and second-guessed. As outlandish a concept as <em>Shaman</em> is, it's grounded in the human reality; the reader knows these characters because the reader <em>is</em> these characters.

</p><p>So often in comics the intent of the writer gets lost in the complexity of the artist’s choices, but not so in <em>Shaman</em>. Bruno Hidalgo’s rendering, linework, composition, and pacing not only complement the tone of Kahn’s rich narrative, they enhance it. Hidalgo understands the beats of graphic storytelling, pausing in all the right moments, and using panel structure and layout to capture the rhythm of action. Hidalgo’s choices as an artist amplify both the comedic and dramatic elements of Shaman perfectly.  

</p><p>Certainly, much of <em>Shaman Volume 1</em> is bonkers and goofy and absurd. But Kahn and Hidalgo are offering much more than Pop Tarts for breakfast here. What is the right thing to do? How do we understand pain and loss in our lives? What does it mean to be a parent, a friend, a hero? <em>Shaman</em> is serving a full meal for dinner – it just happens to be one with a deliciously sweet and fun frosting on top. 

<em>– Daniel Elkin</em></p>]]></description>
    <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><a href="http://winkbooks.net/post/141424962759/shaman-is-bonkers-and-goofy-and-absurd-and">See sample pages from this book at Wink.</a>

<p><em>“He’s the one who makes your whole world possible. This is a world of noble heroes, and savage villains. A world where men and women of great power die everyday. And the Shaman? The Shaman is the one who brings them back.”</em>

</p><p>Ben Kahn and Bruno Hidalgo’s <em><a href="http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/0989907686/thebooklab-20">Shaman Vol. 1</a></em> is, on its surface, an entertaining, fast-paced, self-deprecating story about a guy who raises the dead, his young daughter who wields magic from her mystical tattoos, and a teleporting former superhero-turned-sidekick who travel around bringing back to life those whom “the personification of life itself” tells them to. Along the way, they fight skeletons and Cosmic Guardians and giant green monsters, all the while throwing down quips and wisecracks and pop culture references. It’s fun stuff all around, pulling you in and making you laugh out loud. 

</p><p>But coursing underneath throughout the narrative is an examination of the concepts of right and wrong, good and evil, life and loss, and what it means to be a “family.” Ben Kahn’s storytelling works in the gray areas where nothing is clean cut, and everything, therefore, becomes far more interesting. What could easily be flat, one-dimensional characters are, here, complex, multi-dimensional beings whose motivations and choices are constantly examined and second-guessed. As outlandish a concept as <em>Shaman</em> is, it's grounded in the human reality; the reader knows these characters because the reader <em>is</em> these characters.

</p><p>So often in comics the intent of the writer gets lost in the complexity of the artist’s choices, but not so in <em>Shaman</em>. Bruno Hidalgo’s rendering, linework, composition, and pacing not only complement the tone of Kahn’s rich narrative, they enhance it. Hidalgo understands the beats of graphic storytelling, pausing in all the right moments, and using panel structure and layout to capture the rhythm of action. Hidalgo’s choices as an artist amplify both the comedic and dramatic elements of Shaman perfectly.  

</p><p>Certainly, much of <em>Shaman Volume 1</em> is bonkers and goofy and absurd. But Kahn and Hidalgo are offering much more than Pop Tarts for breakfast here. What is the right thing to do? How do we understand pain and loss in our lives? What does it mean to be a parent, a friend, a hero? <em>Shaman</em> is serving a full meal for dinner – it just happens to be one with a deliciously sweet and fun frosting on top. 

<em>– Daniel Elkin</em></p>]]></content:encoded>
		

		<wfw:commentRss>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/shaman-is-bonkers-and-goofy-an.html/feed</wfw:commentRss>

		<title>Live stream of autonomous virtual deer wreaking havoc in fictional California town</title>
		<link>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/live-stream-of-autonomous-virt.html</link>
		<comments>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/live-stream-of-autonomous-virt.html#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Mar 2016 16:47:49 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Mark Frauenfelder]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Post]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[Delightful Creatures]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[Grand theft auto]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://boingboing.net/?p=453377</guid>
		
		

		<description><![CDATA[<p><img width="640" height="351" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/img_wanderingDeer_02.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="img_wanderingDeer_02" srcset="http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/img_wanderingDeer_02.jpg?resize=300%2C165 300w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/img_wanderingDeer_02.jpg?resize=600%2C329 600w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/img_wanderingDeer_02.jpg?w=640 640w" sizes="(max-width: 640px) 100vw, 640px" /></p><iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/153319249" width="500" height="281" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

<p>From Brent Watanabe:

<blockquote>
<p><a href="http://sanandreasanimalcams.com">San Andreas Deer Cam</a> is a live video stream from a computer running a hacked version of Grand Theft Auto V, hosted on Twitch.tv. The hack creates a deer and follows it as it wanders throughout the 100 square miles of San Andreas, a fictional state in GTA V based on California. The deer has been programmed to control itself and make its own decisions, with no one actually playing the video game. The deer is ‘playing itself’, with all activity unscripted… and unexpected. In the past 48 hours, the deer has wandered along a moonlit beach, caused a traffic jam on a major freeway, been caught in a gangland gun battle, and been chased by the police.

<p>For more information about the San Andreas Deer Cam project, click <a href="http://bwatanabe.com/GTA_V_WanderingDeer.html">here</a>.</blockquote>
]]></description>
    <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><img width="640" height="351" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/img_wanderingDeer_02.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="img_wanderingDeer_02" srcset="http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/img_wanderingDeer_02.jpg?resize=300%2C165 300w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/img_wanderingDeer_02.jpg?resize=600%2C329 600w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/img_wanderingDeer_02.jpg?w=640 640w" sizes="(max-width: 640px) 100vw, 640px" /></p><iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/153319249" width="500" height="281" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

<p>From Brent Watanabe:

<blockquote>
<p><a href="http://sanandreasanimalcams.com">San Andreas Deer Cam</a> is a live video stream from a computer running a hacked version of Grand Theft Auto V, hosted on Twitch.tv. The hack creates a deer and follows it as it wanders throughout the 100 square miles of San Andreas, a fictional state in GTA V based on California. The deer has been programmed to control itself and make its own decisions, with no one actually playing the video game. The deer is ‘playing itself’, with all activity unscripted… and unexpected. In the past 48 hours, the deer has wandered along a moonlit beach, caused a traffic jam on a major freeway, been caught in a gangland gun battle, and been chased by the police.

<p>For more information about the San Andreas Deer Cam project, click <a href="http://bwatanabe.com/GTA_V_WanderingDeer.html">here</a>.</blockquote>
]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Texas man finds fossils from Noah&#039;s flood in his backyard</title>
		<link>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/texas-man-finds-fossils-from-n.html</link>
		<comments>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/texas-man-finds-fossils-from-n.html#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Mar 2016 16:40:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[David Pescovitz]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Post]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[bible]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[fossils]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[Noah's Ark]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://boingboing.net/?p=453371</guid>
		
		

		<description><![CDATA[<p><img width="1280" height="720" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Texas-Man-Says-Fossils-From-Noahs-Flood-Are-Found-In-His-Yard.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="Texas-Man-Says-Fossils-From-Noahs-Flood-Are-Found-In-His-Yard" srcset="http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Texas-Man-Says-Fossils-From-Noahs-Flood-Are-Found-In-His-Yard.jpg?resize=300%2C169 300w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Texas-Man-Says-Fossils-From-Noahs-Flood-Are-Found-In-His-Yard.jpg?resize=600%2C338 600w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Texas-Man-Says-Fossils-From-Noahs-Flood-Are-Found-In-His-Yard.jpg?resize=768%2C432 768w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Texas-Man-Says-Fossils-From-Noahs-Flood-Are-Found-In-His-Yard.jpg?resize=930%2C523 930w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Texas-Man-Says-Fossils-From-Noahs-Flood-Are-Found-In-His-Yard.jpg?w=1280 1280w" sizes="(max-width: 1280px) 100vw, 1280px" /></p><P>
Wayne Propst says that the snail fossils he unearthed in his backyard landed there during Noah's Flood. <a href="http://60abc.com/texas-man-says-fossils-from-noahs-flood-are-found-in-his-yard/">According to 60abc</a>, Joe Taylor, director of the <a href="http://mtblanco.com/about/">Mt. Blanco Fossil Museum</a> in Crosbyton, Texas, "analyzed" the fossils and says that Propst is correct. Taylor is an expert in such matters, arguing on the museum web site that the "fossil record speaks of catastrophic events happening several thousand years ago rather than slow processes taking place over millions or billions of years as is held by the popular establishment."
<P>
James Sagiebiel of the University of Texas's Vertebrate Paleontology Laboratory says Propst's fossils are 35-40 million years old. But what does he know.
<P>
"From Noah’s flood to my front yard, how much better can it get?” Propst said.

]]></description>
    <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><img width="1280" height="720" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Texas-Man-Says-Fossils-From-Noahs-Flood-Are-Found-In-His-Yard.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="Texas-Man-Says-Fossils-From-Noahs-Flood-Are-Found-In-His-Yard" srcset="http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Texas-Man-Says-Fossils-From-Noahs-Flood-Are-Found-In-His-Yard.jpg?resize=300%2C169 300w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Texas-Man-Says-Fossils-From-Noahs-Flood-Are-Found-In-His-Yard.jpg?resize=600%2C338 600w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Texas-Man-Says-Fossils-From-Noahs-Flood-Are-Found-In-His-Yard.jpg?resize=768%2C432 768w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Texas-Man-Says-Fossils-From-Noahs-Flood-Are-Found-In-His-Yard.jpg?resize=930%2C523 930w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Texas-Man-Says-Fossils-From-Noahs-Flood-Are-Found-In-His-Yard.jpg?w=1280 1280w" sizes="(max-width: 1280px) 100vw, 1280px" /></p><P>
Wayne Propst says that the snail fossils he unearthed in his backyard landed there during Noah's Flood. <a href="http://60abc.com/texas-man-says-fossils-from-noahs-flood-are-found-in-his-yard/">According to 60abc</a>, Joe Taylor, director of the <a href="http://mtblanco.com/about/">Mt. Blanco Fossil Museum</a> in Crosbyton, Texas, "analyzed" the fossils and says that Propst is correct. Taylor is an expert in such matters, arguing on the museum web site that the "fossil record speaks of catastrophic events happening several thousand years ago rather than slow processes taking place over millions or billions of years as is held by the popular establishment."
<P>
James Sagiebiel of the University of Texas's Vertebrate Paleontology Laboratory says Propst's fossils are 35-40 million years old. But what does he know.
<P>
"From Noah’s flood to my front yard, how much better can it get?” Propst said.

]]></content:encoded>

		<description><![CDATA[<p><img width="480" height="270" src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/yPMQDW.gif" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="yPMQDW" /></p>https://youtu.be/8YLGXa6Na6U

<p>A North Texas man refused to pull over for police, leading them on a chase through five counties. He was forced to stop after cops set up spikes in the road and shot out his tires. Fox 4 News in Dallas-Fort Worth was on the scene when he was arrested and interviewed him. The drver was remarkably candid about why he did't pull over, explaining that he had weed in his car. "I had weed on me, yeah. I always have weed on me. I'm tired of getting arrested for weed."]]></description>

		<item>
		<title>Watch a submarine crack through pristine ice in the Arctic Circle</title>
		<link>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/watch-a-submarine-crack-throug.html</link>
		<comments>http://boingboing.net/2016/03/21/watch-a-submarine-crack-throug.html#respond</comments>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Mar 2016 16:03:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[David Pescovitz]]></dc:creator>
				<category><![CDATA[Video]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[ice caps]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[military]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[polar]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[submarines]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[US Navy]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[war]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://boingboing.net/?p=453343</guid>
		
		

		<description><![CDATA[<img width="600" height="338" src="http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/160320001506-icex7-super-169.jpg?fit=600%2C338" class="attachment-medium size-medium wp-post-image" alt="160320001506-icex7-super-169" srcset="http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/160320001506-icex7-super-169.jpg?resize=300%2C169 300w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/160320001506-icex7-super-169.jpg?resize=600%2C338 600w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/160320001506-icex7-super-169.jpg?resize=768%2C432 768w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/160320001506-icex7-super-169.jpg?resize=930%2C523 930w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/160320001506-icex7-super-169.jpg?w=1100 1100w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /> <p> <P>
Last week, the United States Navy launched exercises at the new Ice Camp Sargo in the Arctic Circle. Seen above, the nuclear submarine USS Hampton surfaces through the ice. It's a majestic sight, but let's not forget the goal here:
<P>
"(This exercise) is our continued commitment to the development of undersea warfare capabilities and tactics in all areas of the world," said Rear Adm. Jeff Trussler, commander, Undersea Warfighting Development Center. "Our superiority in delivering effects in and from the undersea domain to the operational commanders is dependent on the regular exercise and demonstration of these capabilities."
<P>
I'd imagine that as the polar ice caps melt, and possible energy reserves are uncovered, the region will quickly become a new battleground. Sadly.
<P>
"<a href="http://www.pacom.mil/Media/News/tabid/5693/Article/694476/navy-submarines-arrive-in-arctic-for-ice-exercise-2016.aspx">Navy Submarines Arrive in Arctic for Ice Exercise 2016</a>" <em>(US Pacific Command)
</em>
<P>
<img src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/160320001506-icex7-super-169-930x523.jpg" alt="160320001506-icex7-super-169" width="930" height="523" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-453364" />
<P>
<img src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/160320001629-icex6-super-169-930x523.jpg" alt="160320001629-icex6-super-169" width="930" height="523" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-453365" />]]></description>
    <content:encoded><![CDATA[<img width="600" height="338" src="http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/160320001506-icex7-super-169.jpg?fit=600%2C338" class="attachment-medium size-medium wp-post-image" alt="160320001506-icex7-super-169" srcset="http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/160320001506-icex7-super-169.jpg?resize=300%2C169 300w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/160320001506-icex7-super-169.jpg?resize=600%2C338 600w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/160320001506-icex7-super-169.jpg?resize=768%2C432 768w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/160320001506-icex7-super-169.jpg?resize=930%2C523 930w, http://i0.wp.com/media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/160320001506-icex7-super-169.jpg?w=1100 1100w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /> <p> <P>
Last week, the United States Navy launched exercises at the new Ice Camp Sargo in the Arctic Circle. Seen above, the nuclear submarine USS Hampton surfaces through the ice. It's a majestic sight, but let's not forget the goal here:
<P>
"(This exercise) is our continued commitment to the development of undersea warfare capabilities and tactics in all areas of the world," said Rear Adm. Jeff Trussler, commander, Undersea Warfighting Development Center. "Our superiority in delivering effects in and from the undersea domain to the operational commanders is dependent on the regular exercise and demonstration of these capabilities."
<P>
I'd imagine that as the polar ice caps melt, and possible energy reserves are uncovered, the region will quickly become a new battleground. Sadly.
<P>
"<a href="http://www.pacom.mil/Media/News/tabid/5693/Article/694476/navy-submarines-arrive-in-arctic-for-ice-exercise-2016.aspx">Navy Submarines Arrive in Arctic for Ice Exercise 2016</a>" <em>(US Pacific Command)
</em>
<P>
<img src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/160320001506-icex7-super-169-930x523.jpg" alt="160320001506-icex7-super-169" width="930" height="523" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-453364" />
<P>
<img src="http://media.boingboing.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/160320001629-icex6-super-169-930x523.jpg" alt="160320001629-icex6-super-169" width="930" height="523" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-453365" />]]></content:encoded>

	<title>A prosecutor's vision for a better justice system | Adam Foss</title>
	<itunes:author>Adam Foss</itunes:author>
	<description>When a kid commits a crime, the US justice system has a choice: prosecute to the full extent of the law, or take a step back and ask if saddling young people with criminal records is the right thing to do every time. In this searching talk, Adam Foss, a prosecutor with the Suffolk County District Attorney's Office in Boston, makes his case for a reformed justice system that replaces wrath with opportunity, changing people's lives for the better instead of ruining them.&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/TEDTalks_video/~4/PEPQjX0e2gc" height="1" width="1" alt=""/&gt;</description>

<item>
	<title>Uber's plan to get more people into fewer cars | Travis Kalanick</title>
	<itunes:author>Travis Kalanick</itunes:author>
	<description>Uber didn't start out with grand ambitions to cut congestion and pollution. But as the company took off, co-founder Travis Kalanick wondered if there was a way to get people using Uber along the same routes to share rides, reducing costs and carbon footprint along the way. The result: uberPOOL, the company's carpooling service, which in its first eight months took 7.9 million miles off the roads and 1,400 metric tons of carbon dioxide out of the air in Los Angeles. Now, Kalanick says carpooling could work for commuters in the suburbs, too. "With the technology in our pockets today, and a little smart regulation," he says, "we can turn every car into a shared car, and we can reclaim our cities starting today."&lt;img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/TEDTalks_video/~4/pCLvnTim4z0" height="1" width="1" alt=""/&gt;</description>
	<itunes:subtitle>Uber's plan to get more people into fewer cars | Travis Kalanick</itunes:subtitle>
